name: Preşedinte. -
text: The first item on the agenda was the debate on cases of breaches of human rights, democracy and the rule of law.The first item on the agenda is Sudan - the case of Meriam Yahia Ibrahim (RC-B8-0010 / 2014) (2014/2727 (RSP))

name: Peter van Dalen
text: Author.- Meriam Ibrahim is a Catholic Christian and she is now stuck in the US Embassy in Khartoum with nowhere to go!It is completely unacceptable for the regime in Sudan to hold her on false arguments.She must be able to travel out of the country freely.And that is why I make three calls today: 1. To the government in Sudan to treat her with dignity and to let her go;2. To Catherine Ashton to do her utmost for Meriam Ibrahim's freedom;3. It is up to Pope Francis to make a personal and direct commitment to Meriam's freedom, to invite her to come to the Vatican and have her picked up in Khartoum.In the coming days I will convert these calls into a number of letters and I invite colleagues in the coming days to support and co-sign these letters to get Meriam released from Khartoum.

name: Tunne Kelam
text: author. - Madam President, we are discussing a problem in a nutshell: Meriam Ibrahim’s story reflects a question of principle of universal validity, and the application and practice of such a basic human freedom as freedom of religion and belief, including the freedom to change or abandon a religion. There is ever growing concern that in numerous Islamic states this freedom is seen as a one-way street while the other way, the possibility of converting from Islam to any other religion, is treated as the gravest possible offence. Only two months ago Meriam Ibrahim, being eight months pregnant, was sentenced by a Sudanese court to 100 lashes for so-called adultery, that is for having married a Christian husband, and apostasy, that is for refusing to convert to Islam. We call on the Sudanese Government which has ratified all relevant human rights conventions to allow Meriam and her family to leave the country immediately for safety reasons, and to repeal any legal provisions that penalise individuals for their religious beliefs and to introduce an immediate moratorium on all executions.

name: Javier Nart
text: Author. - Madam President, I do not want to condemn the horrible policy of the Government of Sudan, just as I do not want to continue condemning the Government of Israel for its barbarism in Gaza. I want no more to happen. The case of Meriam Yahia Ibrahim is just one more case, which is the anecdote within the gruesome category that means complete Sudan. Today in Sudan, ongoing massacres are taking place in Yebel Nuba, in western Darfur and in Kordofan. So what we have to do is be proactive. We have tools that are not formal and rhetorical condemnations: we have the capacity, and the capacity is simply called, for example, the Cotonou Accords, effectively binding the democratic clause - which I call the hypocritical clause - because it has never been applied (although is generally Article 2 of all association treaties) or require the necessary democratic activity of a country to continue to maintain privileged ties or special economic, commercial ties of any kind. Therefore, beyond the condemnation of the horrible case of Meriam Yahia Ibrahim is to apply the democratic clause and link our relationship with these countries effectively, with minimal respect for human rights.

name: Judith Sargentini
text: Author. - The reason for this resolution is the imprisonment of Meriam Yahia Ibrahim, a woman who was not allowed to choose her own religion. Meriam is now in the American embassy, ​​the whole world knows her case. That's good, she deserves our attention and protection. But there are many more women and men in prisons in Sudan, women and men who, like Meriam, should not be there. Women, because in the eyes of the regime they have acted immodestly because they wear pants. Women and men for daring to write a newspaper or pamphlet criticizing al-Bashir and his entourage. They are people who need our protection, protection that we can offer them with a resolution in which we mention their names. They have a right that we do not simplify their conflict into a conflict between Muslims and Christians. They are people from Darfur, from the Nuba Mountains, from the Blue Nile, from Kordofan, people who are threatened because of their skin color, their religion, whatever. But also because the regime is not good for anyone. In April, al-Bashir promised to release all political prisoners. It did not happen, the security forces continue to arbitrarily arrest people. In fact, with this resolution, we missed the opportunity to really make a point of the regime in Sudan, which arrests people, activists and civilians, assaults them and puts them in prison without a court for a long time. We should have done that!

name: Josef Weidenholzer
text: Author.- Madam President!Meriam Yahia Ibrahim represents a sad fall of fate. She and her family had to go through incredible things.It is really to be hoped that a positive solution will soon come about personally.The Sudanese government is called upon to do whatever is necessary for their immediate release.This case can also be seen as an example, because here fundamental human rights were violated, the right to freedom of religion and the right to change one's religion, the right to choose a partner and the right to fair legal proceedings, the principle of gender equality and all thatresulting right of equal treatment.Our resolution reminds Sudan that it has committed itself in international treaties to respect and guarantee these rights.The point is that he meets these obligations immediately and in full.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: author. - Madam President, Sudan has been in the grip of one of the worst dictators in the world since the coup that I would describe as military-Islamic in 1989. Secession with South Sudan in 2011 did not help matters. . The border problem, in particular, has never been resolved. Internal conflicts with their share of refugees and displaced people have even increased in recent months. In the north, the sinister Bashir took the opportunity, more than ever, to accentuate the repression and violations of human rights. Yes, Meriam is, indeed, an exemplary case. Today, this region of the world remains one of the main playgrounds of the great world powers. It is linked to the oil manna and other sub-soil wealth, so much so that Sudan is the fourth land of foreign investment in sub-Saharan Africa. But it is also linked to the geostrategic situation of this country. So yes, Western countries have responsibilities. Last January, Bashir announced a national dialogue, but in terms of national dialogue, it is all-out repression that is rife. Worse, NGOs no longer have access to the territory. The humanitarian situation is dramatic. We passed a resolution in October 2013 as an unprecedented wave of protests took place across the country after the removal of fuel subsidies that led to massive tax hikes. Bashir did there, for once, only listen to the international community, the IMF to be more precise. The said international community is therefore more efficient in economic matters than in human rights. The opposition parties under the leadership of the revolutionary front in Sudan have been working on a peace plan for several months. They are now largely assembled, armed opposition or not, official or not. They understood that their disunity played the game of their tyrant. They were within our walls yesterday afternoon, they called us for help. I would like to thank here the parliamentarians from almost all the political groups who sponsored this initiative and who made it possible for a paragraph of this resolution to support this peace process. We must continue to work on this, in particular by applying the human rights clause of the Cotonou agreements and by appointing a high representative for human rights. This is what I am asking you today, Commissioner. It's urgent.

name: Jaromír Štětina
text: for the PPE Group.- Madam President, I will be voting in favor of the resolution on Mrs Marjam Yahya Ibrahim.The death penalty and the punishment of one hundred blows to the pregnant woman's back is barbarism.The judgment is irrelevant even under Sharia law.Mrs. Marjam was brought up as a Christian and therefore cannot be tried for resignation from the faith.I am pleased that the European Parliament is discussing the case of Marjam Jahja Ibráhím.Especially at a time when ethnic and confessional hatreds are provoking new and new armed conflicts in the world.The verdict is an extreme manifestation of radical Islamism, which sheds a dark light on Islam as a great world civilization.Political radical Islamism and the Islamic faith are two different things.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D group. - Madam President! Meriam Yahia Ibrahim, sentenced to death in Khartoum for alleged apostasy from Islam, awaits a new trial. Such a decision was made by the Supreme Court of Sudan, undoubtedly under pressure from many countries and international organizations. The case of 27-year-old Meriam's sentence to death is not unique. Every year, unfortunately, many people in Sudan are killed for this reason, if not by the state then by their own families. Meriam Yahya Ibrahim is a Muslim Shariah; The court therefore declared her marriage to a Christian null and void and her marriage for adultery. The woman was detained in the eighth month of pregnancy. This event is emblematic of the sharpening policy of the Sudanese authorities and the growing intolerance towards religious minorities, the activities of activists, oppositionists and organizations promoting women's rights. But Sudan is also party to the UN treaties on respect for freedom of conscience and religion, and is committed to upholding these values. This also applies to freedom of assembly, freedom of political activity of NGOs and women's organizations.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President! When it comes to persecuting Christians and violating religious freedom, not only declarations are needed, but very specific and decisive acts. It is clear, I support the resolution on Sudan, on the persecution of Meriam Ibrahim, but I would like our actions - the action of the European Union in this matter - to be very determined. Prime Minister Renzi said two weeks ago, "There is no consent to the persecution of Christians." I take his word for it, I want all EU institutions to be very determined and consistent in this matter. We defend Meriam Ibrahim and we defend persecuted Christians not only because of religious freedom, but also because Christianity is the basis of European civilization. There is no Europe without a base of Christianity. These are two strong reasons why we should be very firm in this matter. In this and all other cases, persecution of Christians.

name: Louis Aliot (NI). -
text: Madam President, we are legitimately outraged by the death sentence of Ms. Meriam Yahia Ibrahim Ishag on the pretext that she left Islam to adopt the Christian faith. This particular case poses the problem of religious persecution. Today, 70% of the world's population lives in a country that restricts this freedom. Out of four victims of religious persecution in the world, three are Christians. The main cause is radical Islamism, as in Sudan, Nigeria, Iraq, Yemen, Egypt, Somalia or Pakistan. With the awakening of Islam, Christians in sub-Saharan Africa are increasingly persecuted, even requiring military interventions as in Mali or the Central African Republic. The Arab Spring is now followed by a Christian winter. Beyond the just indignation of the case of Meriam and the pressure exerted on Sudan to prevent this abomination, the European Union must recall the total incompatibility of the values ​​which make our civilization with the totalitarian Islamic law which is progressing everywhere, including included in Europe. Finally, it is becoming urgent to challenge Saudi Arabia and Qatar on their responsibilities in the permanent support they provide to all the religious criminal movements which are developing and progressing in the four corners of the world. (Applause)

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE). -
text: Madam President, the whole international community is shaken by what is happening in Sudan today.Marjam Jahja Ibrahim was guilty of marrying a Christian as the daughter of an Ethiopian Christian woman.In May, a pregnant Marjam was sentenced to one hundred lashes and the death penalty, and it had not yet been said that Marjam had to give birth to her child, literally chained.Marjam is one, but we must ask how many similar Marjam are in Sudan and around the world?Human rights, including freedom of religion, must apply regardless of national borders.The Cotonou Agreement was recalled here, but I would also like to recall that there is a recommendation from the Council of the European Union in June 2013 that makes development aid conditional on explicit respect for religious freedom.Marjam, we in Europe do not forget you!

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D). -
text: Madam President, the situation we are discussing today is extremely important. This is a fundamental violation of human rights, an intolerable violation that the European Union cannot under any circumstances leave unanswered. Mrs. Ibrahim Ishag was arrested and sentenced to death for a question of fundamental freedom, that of the choice of religious affiliation. It is true that while this death sentence has been quashed, the fact remains that Ms. Ibrahim continues to face fabricated charges to prevent her from leaving the country. She had to take refuge in the United States Embassy. Her situation is therefore extremely precarious and we owe it to ourselves to take measures to sanction these decisions taken against Ms. Ibrahim. The Union must imperatively invest itself in order to facilitate its liberation and once again recall the strength of the Union's values. We cannot leave this crime unanswered because, indeed, if she was of Christian faith, we must remember that her father, a Muslim, abandoned her and that it was her mother who raised her and therefore, he there was no apostasy. There is therefore no objective reason to blame him for what he is criticized for today. Let’s do all we can to help him through this difficult ordeal.

name: Andrzej Grzyb (PPE). -
text: Madam President! The case of Meriam Ibrahim is the drama of a woman above all, it is the drama of a mother who could not give birth to her child under normal conditions, but in prison for something that is a normal human right, because every human being has the right to a religion - a specific religion which he himself he chose. She decided that she would be a Christian and also the wife of an American. And she was sent to jail for that, not for committing any crime. On this matter, the European Parliament passed resolutions on the freedom and observance of the rights of Christians in the world. Guidelines on how to proceed through European diplomacy in cases of persecuted religious minorities, including Christian minorities, were also adopted. The matter is serious and this is an example of how Sudan is breaking these rules. As the European Parliament, we cannot remain silent, and I therefore also extend my sincere thanks to everyone who contributed to the tabling of the motions for resolutions. I will vote for it a lot myself.

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D). -
text: Mr President, first of all, thank you to the Bureau for now that human rights issues are at a reasonable time.Last season, the questions were on Thursday night and there were less than ten people here and the voting results could be quite random.This is an important place for human rights issues at a time when there is a widespread perception in many Member States that the only thing that matters in foreign policy is trade.In this way, emphasizing human rights issues is extremely important, because the European Union must have values and not just interests.The case of Meriam Ibrahim is a shocking example, yes, the European Union must now act and show its strength for his release.We must defend him, otherwise the European Union will not really have a foreign policy.There may just be a trade, but it’s not right.

name: Silvia Costa (S&D). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Meriam - a biblical name - imprisoned despite being pregnant, with a child and a handicapped child, condemned for apostasy, or rather for her firmness in not violating her Christian faith, from a symbol of fragility she has become a symbolof strength and courage - as happens to many women in history - but also a strong message for all of us: without religious freedom there is no freedom.Now the European Union must take a strong initiative in the UN more than it has done so far to call Sudan to respect conventions and human rights and to stop the persecutions that in too many parts of the world are particularly affecting, but notonly the Christian communities, communities that often are of dialogue and cultural and social mediation.

name: Androulla Vassiliou
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, we welcome the adoption of Parliament’s urgent resolution on the case of Meriam Yahia Ibrahim. Like you, we have been dismayed that this young mother could be sentenced to death and flogging on charges of apostasy and adultery. Freedom of religion or belief is a universal human right that needs to be protected everywhere and by everyone. Moreover, Sudan has ratified the relevant UN Conventions and African Union instruments and is thus bound to defend and promote this freedom, as was stressed by Mr Weidenholzer. There has been an international outcry against the verdict against Meriam Yahia Ibrahim, which contributed in the end to her release on 23 June by an appeals court. The European Union and Member States have been leading this protest, including with a widely publicised statement by the Presidents of the European Commission, Council and Parliament, together with religious leaders on 10 June. The EU and Member States have also engaged in intensive quiet diplomacy to secure her release. However, on 24 June we learnt with great concern of Meriam’s new arrest, this time on charges of forgery and fraud as she tried to leave the country with South Sudanese travel documents.  We are following the case closely. She has found refuge in the US Embassy in Khartoum and we hope that she will be able to resettle in a life in safety with her family as soon as possible. The legal provisions curtailing freedom of religion or belief remain in place in Sudan. Let us not forget the many Sudanese opposition politicians, journalists, human rights defenders and ordinary citizens who are still being held in prison on the grounds of their convictions, often without charges and in dire conditions. Therefore, we call on the government of Sudan to release these political prisoners and to guarantee the human rights of all its citizens. Only this can create the political space which is urgently needed to bring about peace, reconciliation and democratic governance in a country which remains torn apart by violent conflict and in which there are many Meriams, all of whom deserve our support.

name: Preşedinte. -
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place immediately after the debate.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Monica Luisa Macovei (PPE)
text: in writing. – The recent actions and attitudes of the Sudanese authorities toward Meriam Yahia Ibrahim are outrageous and I condemn them. Sentencing a pregnant woman to a hundred lashes and eventually to death by hanging unless she converts to Islam is a serious breach of human rights and it is absolutely unacceptable. Outrageous and appalling is also the reason for this condemnation: Ms Ibrahim was charged with adultery because of her marriage to a Christian man. According to a statement issued by the Sudanese Embassy in the US, this case is just a legal issue and not a religious or a political one. I disagree. This is torture, discrimination and an alarming violation of the freedom of religion or belief; Sudan is obliged to respect civil rights under the UN and African Union conventions, and under the Cotonou Agreement. Thus, I strongly urge the authorities of Sudan to heed the urging of the European Union, to exonerate Ms Ibrahim and to proceed with legal reforms without delay. As such, I join my colleagues in asking Sudan to stop applying Sharia law to persons who are not of Muslim faith and to ensure the protection of every individual's human rights.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: written. - Mister President! Persecution of Christians is not commonplace in states where Sharia law applies. This is particularly evident in the case of 26-year-old Maryam Yahya Ibrahim Ishaq. She was arrested in August 2013 because she is not only a Christian herself, but also married to one. Her marriage was declared invalid and the "court" sentenced her to death. In addition, 100 lashes before their execution. Had the sentence been carried out, their children - their daughter gave birth in Omdurman Federal Women's Prison and their son also lived in the cell - would have fallen into the custody of the state, since the father, as a Christian, had no right to his children. She was released at the end of June this year because the pressure on Sudan became too strong. Almost a million people signed a petition about it. Such a brutal judgment has been possible since 1983, when Sharia law came into force in Sudan. This provides for the death penalty for "turning away from Islam". Women are also prohibited from marrying non-Muslim men. NGOs such as "Open Doors" see Sudan in 11th place in the "Christian World Persecution Index". Non-Muslims are discriminated against by the state in Sudan and thousands of Christians are punished according to Sharia law.

name: Preşedinte. -
text: The next item is freedom of expression and assembly in Egypt (RC B8-0007 / 2014) (2014/2728 (RSP)).

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: Author. - Egypt is putting Georges Orwell's "1984" handbook into practice. Create a domestic enemy and a foreign enemy, and then say, as President al-Sisi does, "I will protect you in exchange for the loss of your human rights, the loss of the freedom of the press, the democratic right to have your own voice. ". Blame people for serious crimes and then not come up with evidence. The secret services determine what is and what is not true. The state media is selling falsehoods, while the independent press is curbed. Egyptian prisons are psychologically unbearable, according to witnesses. They are overflowing with people who have opposed the government, even more so than under the Mubarak regime. Unabashedly, Westerners are now also being condemned for things they have not done. The Dutch journalist Rena Netjes, who also receives a regrettable mention in our resolution, does not call Egypt Knettergekkistan for nothing, or, as Amnesty International stated earlier, in a somewhat more diplomatic way: Egypt's legal system is broken and unable to administer justice. One step forward to take two steps back. It is a painful lesson for the European Union, namely that the "more for more" principle of the neighborhood policy is of little use.

name: Mariya Gabriel
text: author. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the issues of freedom of expression and assembly clearly show us that our partnership with the Arab Spring countries such as Egypt must still largely focus on democratization. As underlined by the joint resolution, we must call on the Egyptian authorities to put an end to any form of violence or coercion towards journalists, bloggers or any other individual, because of their political or other opinions. Two important messages. The first: the Egyptian authorities must respect freedom of expression and assembly because they are essential for the development of democracy, but even more so to respect their own constitution, this social contract to which citizens subscribed on the occasion of the referendum barely six months ago. As for the second message, the Egyptian authorities must respect international law and international conventions to which Egypt is a party, in particular with regard to the independence and impartiality of the judiciary. Arbitrary detentions, without a credible and thorough investigation, only further cause the social disorder that the authorities would like to control. We will continue to support this neighboring country, but the message must be clear: Egypt must keep its commitments.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada
text: author. - Madam President, I have been a former journalist and press director for almost forty years and would like to salute the two interventions which have just taken place and bear a slightly more personal testimony. The conviction of journalists in Egypt, especially those of Al-Jazeera, after a trial which is a travesty of justice, is truly inadmissible, cannot be passed over in silence and is not negotiable. Because we, elected representatives of the people, need to guarantee freedom of expression. I would like to proclaim in this place, which is concerned with values ​​and should be even more so throughout the world, that as Amnesty International proclaims it, journalism is not a crime. We are not a criminal, Mr. President al-Sisi, on the grounds that, systematically, we do not belong to the family of ideas of the rulers or that we want to explain something other than propaganda. We must remain vigilant on these issues and, fundamentally, freedom of the press is not a journalist's business, it's everyone's business. Through you, I ask the President of the European Parliament to initiate an explicit and solid approach with the Egyptian President so that this scandal of freedom of ideas ends.

name: Judith Sargentini
text: Author. - A year ago the military coup took place in Egypt and I remember the debates in this Parliament. No one dared to say it was a military coup. That the people were actually a bit happy that the military was going to put things in order and that Morsi and his Muslim brothers were gone. God, how wrong we have been! What are you mistaken! I then said, "This is going from bad to worse!" We see activists, we see ordinary citizens, we see journalists disappearing in prison on a large scale; they are locked up for decades with show trials. We see shootings of people who are demonstrating. And this Parliament, as well as our High Representative Catherine Ashton, is not prepared to speak plainly. What have we done? We have simply sent a European observation mission to the presidential elections in Egypt and we have legitimized that case. I would therefore like to say now: ladies and gentlemen, we will stay at home in the next parliamentary elections, because we do not have to legitimize this! My question to Catherine Ashton, to the European Commission is: can we finally stop all so-called preparatory work for cooperation with Egypt? The time is not right! My request to President al-Sisi is: give those Egyptian and those European journalists, including my Dutch compatriot Rena Netjes, freedom and give those activists the space to do what they want to do: say what they think!

name: Josef Weidenholzer
text: Author. - Madam President! For many reasons, the situation in Egypt is of fundamental importance for Europe. It is the most populous country in the neighborhood policy program. Its population of over 80 million represents great future potential. The Arab Spring reached its climax here in 2011 - a time of great hope in Egypt and the European Union. Many saw a new era on the horizon, and entirely new perspectives seemed possible. After three years, this process has stalled and has changed dramatically. There is currently a climate of repression, critical voices in the media are being silenced and criminalized. A law on the right to public assembly, parades and peaceful demonstrations does the exact opposite and allows the authorities to brutally nip civil protests in the bud. There have been countless arrests and convictions over the past few months. Fair trials are the exception and detention conditions are dire. Such a situation is threatening for the people in the country and for Europe. The resolution should be seen as a sign of our deep concern about what is going on, but also as a warning to those in charge of politics. It is therefore logical that the European Union's neighborhood policy is also called upon to make aid dependent on whether progress can be made in the area of ​​human rights and the rule of law.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán
text: Author. - Madam President, at this time we understand that it is important to reiterate the condemnation of the military coup that took place a year ago in Egypt, as well as to condemn and call for an end to the brutal repression by the Army against activists, political opponents, defenders human rights and trade unionists. We must also demand that the Egyptian authorities immediately release journalists imprisoned for reporting legitimate news and reiterate our strong opposition to the death penalty. In our opinion, the European Union should ask the Member States to prohibit the export of military aid to Egypt and remember that association agreements are subject to respect for human rights. We also understand that an appeal must be made to the Egyptian authorities to open the Rafah border to alleviate the suffering of the Palestinian people, who are being massacred in the Gaza Strip by the Israeli Army.

name: Seán Kelly
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa PPE. – A Uachtaráin, tá áthas orm go bhfuil seans agam labhairt ar an ábhar truamhéalach seo, go háirithe mar a bhaineann sé le mo thír féin, Éire, agus go háirithe í gcás Ibrahim Halawa.  Ibrahim Halawa was born in Ireland 18 years ago. Last summer, he travelled to Egypt with his three sisters for a holiday, and they got caught up in the mass demonstrations following the ousting of President Morsi. They were arrested and thrown into prison, like many others, and were kept in inhumane conditions. Ibrahim’s three sisters were released after three months and are now back in Dublin but he has been detained ever since without charge, and is still being kept in inhumane conditions. There was supposed to be a mass trial yesterday but it was postponed. I call on the High Representative and the European External Action Service in Egypt, as a matter of urgency, to do everything they can to get this young man released so that he can go back to Dublin, pursue his studies, as he wishes to do, and become an engineer. He is no threat to anybody. I call for urgent action.

name: Goffredo Maria Bettini
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is really important here because it is Europe's job to defend human rights wherever they are violated. In Egypt the situation is very serious: killing of journalists, death sentences, citizens imprisoned for having expressed their thoughts. It is necessary to ask for the restoration in all possible places of democratic legality. But this resolution is also important because it makes our voice heard in an area devastated by tumultuous political processes and unfortunately also by war. Just look at the situation in Gaza. And it is important because Europe in this area must make its voice heard much more, because we, with our acrobatics and our divisions, have been too silent regarding the problems of an area that is close to us and which it is of enormous importance to us, for historical, cultural, geographical and economic reasons. We need to feel fully involved in these issues.

name: Karol Adam Karski
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President! The rights to freedom of assembly and expression are among the most important in democratic societies and those that aspire to democracy. Nevertheless, the right to religious freedom is important, including the right to practice religion. This law can even be called more important, as it sets the minimum limits for the respect that is due to people who seek fundamental values. It should be noted that this law is also not respected in Egypt, both on the normative level and, above all, in practice. Egypt is one of the most dangerous places in the world for Christians. Their lives are in constant danger there. And they constitute about 10% of the population of this very populous country. Authorities are doing little to protect their communities from the brutal attacks that often involve shooting at defenseless people and burning places of worship. Such attacks are often accompanied by the ostentatious indifference of local authorities. I regret the restriction of the freedom of assembly and speech in Egypt, but we must also keep reminding that much more terrible things are also happening there.

name: Fernando Maura Barandiarán
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, the Government of General al Sisi, with the excuse of guaranteeing security and public order, is cruelly and systematically repressing any type of social protest against its policy, from the criminalization of the Muslim Brotherhood to the incarceration of journalists, politicians and prominent members of civil society, among others. This shows conclusively that hopes for democratic transition under the current government are very weak. Most worrisome is that these developments are taking place in a scandalously arbitrary legal environment, where the basic rights of detainees are constantly being violated. They have failed to unite European partners in a common response to such unfortunate events. Once again we are not united. Europe, whose foreign policy must combine the protection of its interests with the uncompromising defense of the principles of freedom, democracy and respect for human rights, which are the root of its vision of the world, must speak with one voice and ask to the Government of Cairo to respect the fundamental freedoms of all its citizens without exception.

name: Marisa Matias
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, in Egypt the future looks very much like the past. In the last year, we had 1400 deaths in demonstrations. Since January, we have had 1247 death sentences for participating in demonstrations. In the last year, we had 22,000 people also detained in demonstrations. These are the official statistics. It is not even the data, most likely real, that is above this. Democratic rights are called into question, such as the right to demonstrate or freedom of association. There are arbitrary arrests, a ban on political parties. Obviously, we must therefore call on the Egyptian authorities to end these forms of violation and oppression. We must also support the demands of the Egyptian people for justice, for freedom, for human rights. Egypt's future, however, must remain in the hands of the Egyptian people. We will not be able to admit external interference. But there is one thing that the European Union, that the countries of the European Union must do and have an obligation to do, and that is to prohibit the export of security or military equipment, because it is being used to punish people who manifest in a normal way, as it should be in any democracy.

name: Amjad Bashir
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, before the Arab Spring my wife and I visited Egypt, one of the cradles of civilisation. We had a wonderful time, the people seemed happy and content, and we were able to travel in safety. Sadly the situation has changed for the worse. What is happening is denying ordinary Egyptians the opportunity to earn a decent living. When the Arab Spring reached Egypt, it reached the centre of the Arab world. The calls for freedom of expression, in peaceful demonstrations in Tahrir Square, augured well for democracy. A military dictatorship has remorselessly crushed those hopes. In the process, it killed almost 72 people in a single day and it has placed thousands in detention. The role of the army is to defend the nation, not to kill their fellow citizens. Just recently, 46 sentences of life imprisonment and 10 death sentences were handed down, and several more court cases are pending. One hundred and one supporters of a previous, democratically elected government were each sentenced to three years’ imprisonment. It is of the utmost importance to respect the will of the people. I know that this Parliament does not always support democracy. I cite, for example, the Danish referendum on the Maastricht Treaty, which was ignored, and the French and Dutch rejections of the EU constitution, which were swept aside as the EU flagship project was pushed through. With all this in mind, I will be writing to the British Foreign Minister to urge him to express in the strongest terms our disgust at the treatment of innocent Egyptians engaged in peaceful demonstrations. I hope that this will be the new Minister’s first achievement. Democratic principles, especially freedom of expression and the right to assemble in a peaceful manner, are basic human rights.

name: Monica Luisa Macovei (PPE). -
text: Madam President, the situation of the 20 Al Jazeera journalists sentenced by a Cairo court to at least seven years in prison on terrorist-related charges stemming from interviews with the Muslim Brotherhood cannot be tolerated. One of them is Peter Greste. This Australian award-winning journalist went to Cairo to do his job but was unjustly arrested and condemned to prison. Journalism is a profession that is often risky, but journalism is not a crime. Every effort must be made to release immediately the detained journalists. The Egyptian authorities must respect their new constitution. Democracies cannot be built on the political harassment of journalists and arbitrary detention. I strongly urge the government of Egypt to heed the urging of the European Union to release the journalists and review their trials.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, just like my colleague, Seán Kelly, I would like to raise the issue of the continuing imprisonment of the 18 year-old Irish citizen Ibrahim Halawa. Indeed his trial, due to be held yesterday, was postponed. Caught up with his three sisters in a disturbance in a mosque last August on a visit to Cairo, he has been detained without trial since. And by detaining Ibrahim Halawa the Egyptian authorities totally contravene the terms of the EU-Egypt Association Agreement of last June. This Agreement states that respect for human rights and democratic principles constitutes an essential element of the Agreement and in this context his detention without trial and for a prolonged period clearly violates the terms of this Agreement. The fact that Ibrahim’s three sisters, who were arrested with him, were released following representations from the Irish Government clearly indicates they were not engaged in any activity that could justify his detention. I am therefore calling on the High Representative and the Commission to demand the release of Ibrahim, and indeed other journalists who have been detained without trial, and for the cessation of the mass trials. In these trials the rights of the individuals are ignored in a process which has no basis in human rights or acceptable judicial procedure.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, we are one year, almost to the day, from what can certainly be called a military coup. And a military coup remains what it is, unfortunately we see it today, in terms of repression. It is indeed worse than under Mubarak. A year later, the situation is dramatic. We no longer count the arrests, parodies of justice with the key to sentences, including to death, against the Muslim Brotherhood but, more broadly, against all those who dare to defy the power: journalists, rights defenders, activists of opposition. Much has already been said and I want to talk about a specific case. That of Karam Saber, writer, director of an NGO, defending small farmers. Mr. Saber was convicted of contempt for religion, atheism and incitement to massacre, simply because he dared to publish a book on the religious practices of peasants. He was tried on the basis of questionable testimony, after a procedure marred by irregularities. Mr. Saber, like others, must be released. Human rights violations in Egypt must end, the European Union does indeed have the means to put pressure on this country. (The speaker accepts to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Marek Jurek (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- MEP!You spoke about the change of government in Egypt.But are you aware of the situation Egypt was in before this change of power?Churches burned, the geopolitical situation was destabilized, and relations with Israel were destabilized.All this was not for human rights in Egypt, nor for the security of Europe.If we want our humanitarian arguments to be successful, we must fairly assess the situation in this country and the parties to this conflict.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: answer "blue card".- Mister the deputy, we do not know each other yet but you will get to know me and to know that, for me, there are never two weights, two measures in matters of human rights.I did not support the previous government.I just said that the current government is a military government that has taken power militarily and that the situation is worse not only compared to the previous government but compared to the Mubarak regime.It is therefore a negation of the Egyptian revolution and the demands of the Egyptian people in matters of democracy and human rights.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR). -
text: Madam President, I gave a cautious welcome to the intervention that ended the disastrous Morsi government, which had tried to turn Egypt into a one-party state under Sharia law and had brought the economy to its knees. I also gave a cautious welcome to the election of President al-Sisi. But, as a friend of Egypt and a long-standing defender of the large Coptic Christian community which was persecuted under Morsi, I still strongly condemn the harsh and unjust sentences now handed down to the Al Jazeera journalists including my own London constituent Sue Turton. I call again on President al-Sisi to exercise clemency and cancel her unjust 10-year jail sentence, which will make it impossible for her to work as a journalist in any African Union country. So, Mr al-Sisi, please listen to our appeal.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR). -
text: Madam President!I would like to continue what I said before.I believe that we should focus on the appeals for the pardon of the opposition sentenced to death.Severe punishments never solve social problems.We should focus on freeing European journalists who are in Egypt and freedom of speech in general.But all this is not served by disregarding Egypt's conditions for freedom for all, including freedom for Christians, and from preserving Egypt's position as a country that can work constructively with its neighbors.We remember Egypt on the road to social destabilization under previous governments.Therefore, when formulating our harsh judgments, we should always remember that we must address them to the authority that is able to hear them.Such, it seems, was not the authority that in Egypt was removed by the present government.

name: Androulla Vassiliou
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, we welcome the adoption of Parliament’s urgent resolution on the state of freedom of expression and assembly in Egypt and share this House’s concerns. The presidential elections in Egypt at the end of May marked an important step in Egypt’s constitutional road map, which will be completed with the upcoming parliamentary elections likely to be held this autumn.  The EU observed the presidential elections. The team led by Mr Mrio David, concluded in the preliminary statement that the elections were technically administered in line with international standards. However, let me remind Members that the report criticised the overall political environment and found a lack of respect for fundamental freedoms and human rights due to political polarisation. It expressed concerned at the clamp-down by the authority on the Muslim Brotherhood and on political opposition. The deteriorating human rights situation, including restrictions on the freedom of expression and of assembly is of great concern to us, and we call on the Egyptian authorities to ensure universal participation in the upcoming parliamentary elections. If not addressed, this issue will cast yet another shadow on Egypt’s transition towards democracy. Recent judicial proceedings against many civil society activists, media and supporters of the political opposition have been marked by a lack of respect for due process and by disproportionate sentences, notably on the occasion of the recent mass trials passing death sentences. We have denounced this and have called for the review of these sentences. Moreover, we are concerned to see that the death penalty was implemented on 16 and 19 June. It should be recalled that the EU is opposed to capital punishment in all cases, and calls for its abolition. We are gravely concerned at the sentences pronounced against the Al Jazeera journalists, including EU citizens, as was recalled by Mr Kelly, as well as those pronounced in absentia against other European journalists, and at the heavy jail sentences against prominent activists. We are closely following these cases through our delegation in Egypt. We call on the Egyptian authorities to allow media and civil society activists to operate freely. In this respect, I would like to refer to the EU guidelines on freedom of expression adopted last May in which we clearly state that ‘all governments must allow journalists to work in a free and enabling environment in safety and security, without the fear of censorship or restraint’. Finally, we worry about the continued detention of human rights activists arrested as they were demonstrating against the protest law. We have repeatedly called on the Egyptian authorities to allow peaceful protests. The protest law will need to be amended. We are fully aware of the volatile security situation and have condemned terrorist attacks, but fighting terrorism should not result in measures which de facto violate civil liberties and freedoms. Let me conclude by saying that we are monitoring newly-adopted legislation, such as the protest law, and draft legislation, such as the NGO law and counter-terrorism law, with regard to their compliance with human rights. In this respect, the last draft of the NGO law is very worrying as it discriminates against European NGOs. The EU stands ready to offer assistance to Egypt to bring its legislation in line with its international human rights obligations. Egypt, as we all know, is a key neighbour and partner in the region. We shall therefore remain constructively and critically engaged to address all restrictions on human rights, freedom of assembly and freedom of speech. At the same time, we stand by Egypt and support its transition towards democracy and economic prosperity.

name: Preşedinte. -
text: The debate is closed.Voting takes place immediately after these debates.

name: Preşedinte. -
text: The next item on the agenda is the situation in Nigeria - recent attacks by Boko Haram (RC B8-0016 / 2014) (2014/2729 (RSP)).

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: author. - Madam President, just one year ago, we addressed the issue of the atrocities committed by the terrorist group Boko Haram in Nigeria in an emergency resolution. It is clear that things have only worsened in the meantime, armed attacks, suicide bombings, kidnappings and other violent acts committed by this terrorist sect against civilians and government forces have multiplied and we must them. condemn without reservation. At the same time, we must demand the immediate release of the girls abducted from the school in Chibok, whose tragic story has moved the entire international community. Finally, I would like to stress that I find the proliferation of jihadist Islamist groups and their sectarian violence very worrying, whether it be Boko Haram in Nigeria, Aqmi or An-Sardine in Mali, or even 'Al-Chabab in Somalia, these terrorist groups have become a growing threat to anyone who does not adhere to their beliefs, and it is our duty to help the countries concerned to combat them.

name: Louis Michel
text: author. - Madam President, the Islamist group Boko Haram seriously threatens the stability of the country, the sub-region and the region as a whole. Of course, we strongly condemn all the atrocities committed by this group against the civilian population, and particularly the kidnapping of more than 270 schoolgirls from Chibok high school. Those responsible for these unspeakable acts must obviously be tracked down and brought to justice. If we do not want Boko Haram to join forces with other criminal drug trafficking movements, such as AQIM, the Islamic State and the Mujao at the gates of Europe, we need an effective response. And it must be said that our declarations which resound in an incantatory manner are obviously not enough. It is certainly essential to combine security issues with those of development and the promotion of human rights, to work on education, health and anti-corruption programs. Only national, regional, European and international cooperation can fight these groups. But I remain convinced that there will never be a real European international policy without a military capacity capable of using coercion and force when necessary.

name: Charles Tannock
text: author. - Madam President, Boko Haram, in one of its most recent heinous attacks, led an assault on a village in Borno State, killing 44 people and burning down three churches. They believe that Western education is a sin and they hold in contempt the education of young women and the presence in Nigeria of religious minorities – particularly the Christians. Boko Haram is part of an axis of terrorism that spreads across the Sahel, beginning with Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM)and including Al-Shabaab in Somalia, and stretches across the Middle East, where we see leading groups such as the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS), as far as Afghanistan and Pakistan, with the Taliban. The UN must now begin to seek a dedicated international policy – uniting the European Union, the United States, Russia, India and China, all of whom have an interest in fighting global terrorism – and must look at this phenomenon in its entire global context, rather than pursuing the current piecemeal approach. In countries like Nigeria, where 70% of the population is living on little more than a dollar an day, there is fertile ground for small groups of extremists exploiting individuals in desperate search of work, food and stability. With a weak state, boasting only inadequate security forces, and with corruption in Nigeria endemic, Boko Haram is flourishing. It is dangerously destabilising a fragile country and dividing the Muslim majority of the north from the Christian majority of the south. The response of the government so far is woefully inadequate.

name: Jean Lambert
text: author. - Madam President, earlier this year the world was absolutely shocked by the abductions and the violence in Chibok and we saw the strong reaction from civil society in Nigeria, from people who do support education for boys and girls – for the attacks of Boko Haram are not only on girls – people who want change in Nigeria, people who want action against Boko Haram, who want accountability from their government and the conviction of those responsible for atrocities. Obviously we express our sympathy for the friends and the families, not only of the girls from Chibok, but of all of those of different faiths who have been abducted, injured and murdered over the years by the growing violence of Boko Haram and the often violent state pursuit which has all too often substituted indiscriminate force for targeted action. Nigeria recently became the biggest economy in Africa and we have heard about the great inequality within regions and between north and south. There is an enormous distrust of the government. Where you have that distrust you are not going to get information and people do not feel protected. A major complaint of civil society has been about the apparent absence of the government response. So we would support the action that has been taken by a number of governments in helping on Chibok, but we would hope to see a more concentrated response from the government in Nigeria in coordination with governments elsewhere.

name: Linda McAvan
text: author. - Madam President, it is almost one hundred days since these girls disappeared and I think we should pledge today that we will keep on campaigning until the girls are released and not let this issue go off the headlines. I agree with Jean Lambert: we need to work together; we need to urge the Nigerian Government to do everything possible to make that happen. But in the long term we need to do more.  In the MDGs we pledged that every child should receive an education but as 2015 approaches there are thousands of schools closed in Nigeria because of terrorist attacks. The international community is now looking at what should replace the MDGs and it is clear that safe schools need to be part of what we are talking about. I want to praise the work of former British Prime Minister Gordon Brown and his wife Sarah who have worked to set up an initiative spearheading safe schools and are putting this on the top of the international agendas on international development. Yesterday I met UNICEF which reminded us that later this year we will mark 25 years since the signing of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. We must do everything we can here to make sure that every child has their rights respected.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez
text: Author.- Madam President, once again, in the name of a cause, a religion or an ideology, the patriarchy shows its true face.This time in the form of violence against women and against girls whose only crime is exercising their right to go to school.We want their immediate release and we want the guarantee that these and all other girls will be able to attend school.With horror we see, once again, how in cases of conflict women are used as trophies, objects and bargains.I want to express our outrage and call on institutions and society to strengthen the fight for equality and guarantee respect for the rights of women around the world and in all situations.

name: Mariya Gabriel
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, the message of our resolution is clear: attacks and violence must stop. Kidnapped girls and children must be released immediately. This is the message we send to the terrorist sect Boko Haram, but it is also a message for the Nigerian authorities and regional partners. Boko Haram attacks are a symptom of dysfunctions that require broader efforts. I will focus on two types of action. At the national level, the reform of the security and justice sector must be pursued so that the Nigerian authorities can fight terrorism while respecting human rights and international law. Then, at the level of regional cooperation, we know that part of Boko Haram's funding comes from the trafficking of arms, drugs and human trafficking and that Boko Haram has rear bases in neighboring countries, cooperation is essential, especially for information sharing. Today, ECOWAS and the African Union must also translate declarations into action. Regional cooperation is all the more important as the development of Boko Haram also threatens the neighboring region. Finally, Bring back our girls!

name: Ana Gomes
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, the Boko Haram group, with links to Al-Qaida, is in a terrorist campaign against the people of Nigeria, at an unbearable human cost, triggering a humanitarian crisis. There are already at least 2000 civilians killed in 95 attacks since the beginning of this year 2014. Many of these crimes constitute real crimes against humanity that need to be investigated and punished by the Nigerian authorities and the International Criminal Court, which has already opened an investigation preliminary, as Nigeria is a State Party to the Rome Statute. The Nigerian Government, with the assistance of the European Union and the international community, needs to dedicate all its efforts to protect its people from these attacks, in particular the women and girls who have been particularly targeted by Boko Haram's odious fate. But it also needs to address Nigeria's fundamental problems, with widespread corruption, notably in the armed and security forces, the diversion of oil funds, inequality and a lack of respect for the basic rights of the Nigerian people. All of these factors contribute to poverty, violence and growing radicalism in Nigeria. Development aid in Nigeria must focus on removing the causes of Boko Haram's rise.

name: Bas Belder
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - The suffering of Christians in Northern Nigeria is deep. After all, Boko Haram has continued to murder and plunder over the past two months. Attacks on villages, bomb attacks on busy places and on Christian targets. In addition, there are the so-called "silent killings": individual Christians, often pastors or church leaders, are systematically murdered in cold blood. Reliable local sources point again and again to growing numbers of individual Christians being killed and whose coverage is not getting through to world news. The European Union has now designated Boko Haram as a terrorist organization. I therefore urge the Council and the Commission to hold the Nigerian government to account firmly and persistently for its basic responsibility towards its own Christian community, which is in acute danger every day. Because there is no adequate protection or adequate government assistance to the victims of Boko Haram's unbridled violence. I expect the European Union, as a legal community, to take care of the Nigerian Christians with an open ear and an open eye! [The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.]

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- Madam President!I would like to ask Mr Belder if he thinks that possible sanctions against the government in Nigeria could cause that government to actually fight this sect, because we have the impression that the government of Nigeria is either unable or unwilling to carry out any real action to combat this sect.terrible, hitting children, women, not only men, the sect?

name: Bas Belder (ECR)
text: "blue card" answer.- Thank you, Mr Czarnecki, you are absolutely right that we must be very concerned about the attitude of the NigerianPerverted by supporters of Boko Haram, Nigerian Christians are currently no longer confident in the law enforcement methods of the Nigerian government.I therefore believe that the Council and the Commission should indeed enter into an urgent discussion with the Nigerian authorities or otherwise impose sanctions.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, I join in condemning the kidnapping of the girls from the Chibok school. Once again, sexual violence against women and girls is used as a weapon of war. I repudiate the violence of Boko Haram and its fundamentalism, as well as the crimes and the larvae war that is going on in northern Nigeria - of course! - but my reflection goes further. Nigeria has been, since 2013, the richest country in Africa - its gross domestic product already exceeds that of South Africa - and it not only lives on oil: it has a flourishing cultural and telecommunications industry, but 60% of the population lives with little more than a dollar a day. Think of the despair that this produces and the breeding ground it provides for all kinds of extremisms. The inhumanity of Boko Haram must be fought - undoubtedly - but it is also inhumane, unacceptable that such a rich country deserves the 153rd place on the United Nations Human Development Index. Institutional corruption and the unfair and unequal distribution of wealth also need condemnation and solutions, because they also kill and cause too many people to have nothing to lose, even their own lives. That is why today I call for the immediate release of the girls.

name: Heidi Hautala
text: On behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - (FI) Mr President, the case of the Chibok girls reveals in a shocking way how women's and girls' rights are being trampled on in the world. We must work at all levels so that we can safeguard these rights. Malala, a Pakistani schoolgirl who was herself a victim of the Taliban, is currently in Nigeria and has told Boko Haram leaders, “Don’t abuse Islam”. She has also clearly received international attention for the fact that the case of these girls is very important in defending the rights of women and girls. I would like to draw attention to the fact that a very important concern for women's and girls' rights is that their sexual and reproductive health rights are being trampled on all over the world. And I hope that the European Union will continue to work internationally for these rights, so that every girl and woman has the opportunity to control her own body, decide on her own life, and not submit to the commodity, sexual slavery of such groups and lose every opportunity to live in dignity. These girls need to be released. International attention must remain in Nigeria until they are free.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, since the beginning of 2014 the attacks of the jihadist terrorist organization Boko Haram have caused at least 2,500 deaths. Nigeria is the eighth country in the world for oil production. Too bad that most of its 148 million inhabitants live below the poverty line. European funding for peace and the resolutions of this Parliament have been of no use given that the terrorist organization has strengthened and that the socio-economic conditions of the country have significantly worsened. Many sources reveal that Boko Haram was born in 2009 but is only strengthened with interventions in Libya and Syria, coincidentally when France and England begin to send vehicles, weapons and fighters to Africa. Additionally, an investigation released by the Nigerian Tribune explains how a London-based charity organization, the Al Mundada Trust Fund, would raise money for Boko Haram. Ladies and gentlemen, I wonder if it is not in the European institutions' interest to intervene to put an end to this bloodbath by resolutely seeking the financiers of this jihadist terrorist organization Boko Haram.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI). -
text: Madam President, Nigeria, an African country, and Greece, a European country, differ in many areas. But they look like countries in the extent of the corruption of political and social inequalities. Their central governments are painless to the people and illegalities of MPs and ministers, with the cooperation of political parties, are not brought to justice. In Nigeria, the actions of Boko Haram and Ansaru are diverting public opinion from the real problems. Terrorist attacks are throwing ashes in the eyes of the people. The so-called development model covers the real problems, in order to survive the policies and to serve business interests. I wonder, however, how it is possible for the European Parliament to be indifferent to illegalities within its Member States and to deal with its neighborhood? In Greece, the co-government, serving selfish purposes with the assistance of the executive and the judiciary, has established a peculiar dictatorship. There is no Boko Haram and Ansarou in Greece. There are corrupt judges, corrupt politicians, bribery of state agents and political persecution of opponents. Thus, the General Secretary and 8 deputies of the Golden Dawn, the third political force, were taken to prison on trumped-up charges on the orders of Prime Minister Samaras. A number of Members of Parliament, in violation of Article 19 of the UN, have unconstitutionally banned freedom of opinion, expression and speech.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE). -
text: Madam President! The European Parliament resolution on the situation in Nigeria is very important and I therefore strongly support it. The terrorist and criminal organization Boko Haram not only kills but, as its name implies, also destroys education and culture. In April of this year, more than 200 girls were kidnapped from the school and could be sold as slaves. This dramatic information has already spread around the world. Most of us in this Parliament are not only Members but also parents. After all, children are our whole world. Therefore, everything must be done so that the kidnapped students return to their family homes. The key to this is determined action and close cooperation between the government of Nigeria, the European Union, the African Union and the United Nations. One should also remember to provide all help to the families of the abducted persons. In the long term, the European Parliament should take measures to promote security, stability and respect for human rights in Nigeria.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, with the debate the ignorance which is at the root of poverty and hunger is overcome. These words are from an extraordinary Italian and European woman, Rita Levi Montalcini. Not surprisingly, Madam President, the name of the terrorist sect Boko Haram can be translated like this: Western education is a sin. The point therefore is the right to education of women, as well as of every person. Access to education is a fundamental right, since it is not an end in itself, but constitutes the road and the precondition for the exercise of other rights. Hence our commitment to any action that sees the return of girls home and the cessation of the Boko Haram terrorist movement. Madam President, I propose that mothers of kidnapped Nigerian girls be nominated for the Sakharov Prize 2014 for their commitment to the defense of fundamental human rights. Bring back our girls, rendez-nous nos filles!

name: Diane Dodds (NI). -
text: Madam President. I am glad to take part in this debate today and to see a focus on those persons who suffer persecution because of their faith. The case of the capture of the young girls in Nigeria is extremely troubling. Belatedly it has brought international focus on the situation in northern Nigeria where thousands of Christians and those of faith have been slaughtered by Boko Haram. In the last legislature, along with my colleague Mr Belder, I hosted Christians from northern Nigeria in the Parliament. One man told his story. He had been asleep when Boko Haram came to his home. They brought him out, and asked him to renounce his faith or be shot. When he refused he was shot in the face. When they left he asked his wife to go to the other Christian men in the village to get help to take him to hospital. She came back to tell him that he was the only one who had survived. These are the stories of thousands across northern Nigeria: men, women, families, targeted because of their faith. It is wrong; let this Parliament have the courage to call it as it really is – the persecution of those of faith.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, this week the Islamist group Boko Haram launched several deadly attacks in Nigeria in addition to the many deaths for which they have already been responsible since their creation. These attacks come on top of the hostage-taking of more than 200 young girls kidnapped on April 14 in Chibok in the northeast of the country. Despite a significant mobilization of the international community but also of social networks, their fate is still uncertain and each passing day makes people fear the worst. If, unfortunately, we can only condemn and sadly witness all of these abuses, it is more necessary than ever to affirm our support for the Nigerian government in order to really fight against Boko Haram, in particular through the presence of our diplomats on but, no doubt, also through targeted military aid to fight against this scourge. More than ever, whatever our political sensitivities, our Parliament must unite and speak with one voice in order to never accept the unacceptable.

name: Georg Mayer (NI). -
text: Madam President, esteemed colleagues! Translated, Boko Haram means nothing else than “books are sin” or “education is sin”. It is not, as a colleague previously said from another side, the patriarchy that shows its face here, it is radical Islam that shows its face here. We have to be aware of that. What we are witnessing here is one of the most radical Islamic terrorist groups there is in this world and in Nigeria. But there are also other countries. The crimes committed by this group in the past few months have hit the headlines. We have already heard from some colleagues today what it is about. These are headlines that are really terrifying, that shake deep into the core. There are about 300 schoolgirls who were kidnapped. In early July, 60 people were slaughtered. These are dramas that take place in families that we cannot really address here. This is one of the most terrible excesses of radical Islam. There is also one in Europe, and it must feel our full severity and the full severity of our law.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D). -
text: Madam President!The brutal terrorist attacks by Boko Haram in northern Nigeria destabilize the entire region.Since 2010, thousands of people, including many children, have died as a result of attacks on public institutions, schools and churches.In April this year.over 200 girls were abducted from a government high school.The fate of most of them is still unknown.The bloody Boko Haram attacks caused a global humanitarian crisis in the country, from which over 10,000 people fled to neighboring countries.To improve the situation, reforms to combat poverty and unemployment, while building strong state institutions, including a stable and credible judicial system, will be of key importance.Nigerian authorities must ensure the safety of their citizens and say NO to the actions of the Islamic militia.

name: Androulla Vassiliou
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, honourable Members, we remain concerned about the situation in Nigeria, where a series of violent attacks continue to terrorise the population. The High Representative, Cathy Ashton, has strongly condemned the indiscriminate killing of hundreds of civilians and the abduction of more than 200 schoolgirls in Borno state. We continue to call for the immediate and unconditional release of the schoolgirls and for those responsible to be brought to justice. Our thoughts are also with the families of the girls, who are desperate to see their children return home safely. The violence in Nigeria has taken a heavy toll on the population. Since 2009 the insurgencies has cost nearly 5 000 lives, displaced close to half a million people, destroyed hundreds of schools and government buildings and devastated an already-weak economy in the north-east. Most worryingly, since the beginning of this year attacks have occurred on an almost daily basis and since January alone between 1 500 and 2 000 innocent people have been killed. The EU listed Boko Haram as a terrorist organisation last month, one day after their designation by the UN, demonstrating the EU’s firm and determined condemnation of the group’s unacceptable criminal activities which touch upon both Christians and Muslims.  The root causes of violence and radicalisation will continue to be addressed through the European Development Fund. The new fund will focus its activities in particular in the north of the country, supporting the health and energy sectors. The EU is also present in Nigeria with humanitarian assistance under ECHO providing EUR 5 million to the north-eastern states, particularly in response to the on-going food and nutrition crisis. On the political tack, human rights remain at the top of our agenda with Nigeria, including in our regular ministerial dialogues. Possible human rights abuses perpetrated by the Nigeria military have to be investigated and those responsible brought to justice. The EU stands with the people and government of Nigeria in the fight against terrorism and violence, and for the rule of law and human rights. We are working with the Nigerian authorities to help bring an end to the cycle of violence through many actions, including continuous political dialogue and targeted aid interventions focusing on the underlying root causes of violence.

name: Preşedinte. -
text: The debate is closed.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: The next point is the vote.(Voting results and other details of voting: see Minutes).

name: Daniel Caspary (PPE). -
text: Vice President Wieland, dear colleagues! In accordance with Rule 22 (4) of our Rules of Procedure, the President of Parliament represents the European Parliament externally. We jointly determine Parliament's positions in votes in which we sometimes win and sometimes lose. But as Democrats, we accept the results. Yesterday President Schulz represented Parliament at the Council Summit in Brussels. Here he has again expressed his own opinion and not the decisions of the House. An example: Parliament set its positions on investment protection in the report by former socialist colleague Kader Arif with a large majority. The resolution of the socialist colleague Vital Moreira on TTIP also found a large majority. If even our President does not take our decisions seriously, then we need not be surprised if the Council, the Commission or the Eurosceptics do not take us seriously either. Now that this has happened repeatedly, we ask all of you that in the future the President and the services of this House ensure that the official views of this House are represented on official occasions. (Applause)

name: Der Präsident. -
text: Thank you very much, Mr Caspary!We will investigate this process.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mister President!I would ask the Bureau to consider whether we can set up a committee to review the correct representation of the decisions of this House, which monitors the President 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.(Applause)

name: Jacek Saryusz-Wolski (PPE). -
text: Mr President, we wish to add the following phrase: ‘and calls on rebels and mercenaries to do the same and not use civilians as human shields’.

name: Jacek Saryusz-Wolski (PPE). -
text: Mr President, at the end of the text we wish to add the following words: 'and calls on all sides to do their utmost to protect civilians and to allow for Ukrainian humanitarian assistance'.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: Mr Saryusz-Wolski!We had the vote on Amendment 9, which was adopted.The text under item 8 is thus obsolete.You have just read out an oral amendment that you proposed to paragraph 8.But that no longer affects the situation.You wanted to table an amendment to paragraph 12.The oral amendments concern paragraph 12 not paragraph 8. Paragraph 8 fell.Do you want to move an amendment to paragraph 12?- Before the vote on Amendment 11:

name: Jacek Saryusz-Wolski (PPE). -
text: Mr President, at the end, after the word ‘rhetoric’, we wish to add the three words ‘including from Russia’, with it then continuing ‘which may further aggravate the conflict’.

name: Jacek Saryusz-Wolski (PPE). -
text: Mr President, we have an oral amendment to the oral amendment by the Greens, proposing that on the third line of this amendment we delete the words ‘as well as the decision of the Hungarian Government to sign an agreement on nuclear energy with Russia’. So, this text as it is proposed by the Greens in Amendment 5, with a deletion in the third, fourth and fifth lines – deleting ‘as well as the decision of the Hungarian Government to sign an agreement on nuclear energy with Russia’.

name: Georg Mayer (NI). -
text: Mister President!May I make a suggestion?Although I am new to the House, I still have parliamentary experience.Do not be mad at me.But it would be good if we at least had the time to raise our hands accordingly between “for”, “against” and “accepted”.You're doing this a little too quickly.(Applause)

name: Der Präsident. -
text: Mr Mayer!I like to try.But you will quickly notice that colleagues grumble when things go too slowly.Because if you need ten minutes longer here - everyone is waiting for the plane and I am doing this at the pace that has leveled off in the last Parliament.You also have well-prepared voting lists from your employees.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D). -
text: Mr. Chairman, it appears that there has been a technical adjustment to paragraph 6. It is July 15 instead of July 14.‘Welcomes the election of the new speaker of the Iraqi Parliament on 14 July 2014’.Actually this should be changed to the 15th.It is just a technical amendment.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: Thank you, Mrs Gomes, for pointing this out.We will review and correct that.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: The voting time is now closed.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: Carlos Jiménez Villarejo has given notice in writing of his resignation as member of the European Parliament with effect from August 1, 2014.Pursuant to Article 4 (3) of the GO, Parliament shall determine that the seat has become vacant from that date and shall inform the national authority concerned.

name: Jörg Leichtfried (S&D). -
text: Mister President!I fully understand that you did not wish to continue this debate beforehand.I just wanted to express my satisfaction with the way you conducted the meeting.You're doing an excellent job.I would recommend the gentlemen at the top right to concentrate a little more.Then it would be fine.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR). -
text: Mr President, the ECR Group welcomes the election and decisive victory of President Poroshenko, who by adopting a progressive military approach has had some success recently, with the liberation of Sloviansk, and who has pledged to broker a ceasefire agreement on the essential condition that this is fully observed by both sides and all hostages are freed. However, should Russia not cease its military support for rebel groups operating in eastern Ukraine and destabilising the entire country the EU must not hesitate to progress to sectoral economic sanctions against Moscow. Indeed, the EU must take the lead in advocating a peaceful political solution to the Ukrainian crisis that brings an end to the militant-driven violence, abductions, executions and political intimidation that have hitherto characterised this tragic conflict. Such a solution must crucially respect the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine, including Crimea, which Russia so gracefully annexed on the basis of a pack of lies. It is clear that the nomination of Federica Mogherini as High Rep is causing concerns in Member States like Poland and the three Baltic States because of perceived pro-Russia bias from the Rome government.
