So that government should now, under the Italian Presidency, instead use this platform to promote regional stability following the recent successful conclusion of association agreements and EU FTAs with Ukraine, Moldova and Georgia, thereby seeking instead to respect the European aspirations of these sovereign countries. Prime Minister Renzi should not for purely commercial reasons seek to appease Russia, which under Putin is seeking to re-establish through the Eurasian Economic Union an authoritarian version of the old Soviet Union and to introduce revanchist and irredentist claims which should have no place in the modern world.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE). -
text: With regard to Ukraine, a number of issues remain unresolved. However, changing the constitution should ensure the peace of society and the functioning of the country in the long run. It is inconceivable that the amended Basic Law should not focus on taking into account regional differences, formalizing the languages ​​in use and guaranteeing the rights of national minorities. I am convinced that a democratic, sovereign and human rights-guaranteed Ukraine can only succeed in the future if it takes into account the interests and values ​​of all its citizens, regardless of their nationality and mother tongue: Ukrainian, Russian, Hungarian or Romanian. It is therefore important that a real decentralization takes place with the constitutional amendment, as greater involvement of local authorities in the life of communities can promote not only the unity of the country but also its modernization. I wish you a lot of wisdom and courage to carry out this process.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI). -
text: Mr President, why did we vote against the main and majority resolution?Because this resolution bypass the coup, the establishment of an insurrectionary government, the vote of the newly elected president in a country in civil war.This resolution seeks to prevent continental unity with Russia to keep up with US imperialism.This is not a peace resolution, it is a propaganda resolution!

name: Janusz Ryszard Korwin-Mikke (NI). -
text: We voted against because the resolution is one-sided.The resolution unnecessarily irritates his Excellency Vladimir Putin, who must very much defend himself against pressure in Russia - defend himself against accusations that he does not bring troops to Ukraine to defend his countrymen.We consider such unilateral attacks unfair.An independent, strong Ukraine is in the interest of my country, but this does not mean that we have to offend people who we don't like.I agree with my colleague Schaffhauser that we are dealing here with American aggression, which is looking for an excuse to declare war, because both military forces and the threat of US bankruptcy make it worth making a war now, as debts are not paid during the war.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, we have voted against the Resolution because we denounce the complicity, the collaboration, of the institutions of the European Union with the Government of Ukraine, a government resulting from a coup, a government with the presence of neo-Nazis.Once again, the European Union has taken the side of the economic interests of certain multinationals and the geopolitical interests of the United States, instead of taking the side of the people and peoples that make up Ukraine.We ask for an independent commission of inquiry to clarify the massacre on May 2 in Odessa, where more than 40 people were killed at the House of Trade Unions, apparently at the hands of members of far-right organizations.We are clear that the extreme right must be stopped throughout Europe and also in Ukraine.

name: James Carver (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, if we were to accept this resolution, which is clearly aimed at warmongering politicians, this would also have a chilling effect on civilised nations taking action to protect peace and act on crimes against humanity. By the way this resolution has been drafted, senior military personnel who took careful advice before Iraq 2 would possibly face prosecution. Hence, we voted against, regrettably letting the politicians off the hook.

name: Tatjana Ždanoka (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President, I voted against this resolution. I am shocked that a number of colleagues who were authors of the EPʼs previous nine resolutions on the Ukraine-Eastern Partnership countries and Russia, based on a so-called zero sum game approach to our relations with Ukraine – these resolutions adopted in September to April – do not feel their responsibility for the terrible bloody events in Ukraine in May, June and July. Why did you take the word ‘Odessaʼ out of the drafts? You are continuing to produce exactly the same kind of texts based on treating those in Ukraine who are against European accession unequally with those who are in favour. You even deprive the first category of the right to be Ukrainians: see paragraph 8 of the resolution. I want to remind you that according to an independent survey conducted in December immediately after the Maidan revolt was launched, 49% of Ukrainians identified themselves as supporters of Maidan while 45% were opposed to it. As regards foreign actors: Russia is mentioned 33 times in the said resolution while the United States is not mentioned at all ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Andrus Ansip (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I welcome the line taken by the June European Council on Ukraine and agree with the resolution. In spite of the very concrete and clear 27 June conclusions and the deadline set there is no real progress in fulfilling them. It is right to provide Russia with possibilities to prove it is cooperating in solving the crisis in Ukraine but we cannot keep postponing our decisions on reaction measures indefinitely yet again. Furthermore, instead of fulfilling the conditions and cooperating with Ukraine we are seeing precisely the opposite: Russia continues to supply the separatists with forces and weapons. The EU should clearly state that any retaliatory measures by Russia will not be tolerated and will have serious consequences.  By now we should be ready to implement more targeted sanctions, including no (new) investments, suspension of different forms of EU financial support, new sector projects and programmes, no high-tech or new technology as well as an arms embargo. We see the sanctions as mostly having a preventive rather than a punitive effect. We may face very serious and direct consequences in the future as Russia sees that no real steps will be taken no matter what.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. - The democratic Maidan phenomenon, which has given birth to the Ukrainian people's hope of living in a free, democratic and European country, requires the full and strong support of the European Union. Signing of the Association Agreement between the European Union and Ukraine this year June 27 paved the way for qualitatively different collaborations. The implementation of the approved free trade agreement is undoubtedly the right step, which meets the expectations of both parties. The path of Ukraine's new government in the fight against corruption, strengthening the country's governance, improving economic governance and guaranteeing civil rights, based on strong political power, has received the support of the democratic world and, unfortunately, hostile opposition from the Russian Federation. The unprecedented and false information propaganda campaign launched and still being carried out by Russia against Ukraine and the West is directed against the principles of peaceful existence of neighboring countries. The process of direct Russian aggression against Ukraine, ignoring international agreements and other OSCE principles, has reached a critical point. The Russian Federation bears direct responsibility for the numerous deaths of peaceful people in southeastern Ukraine. The Russian Federation continues to illegally occupy Crimea. The European Union must remain an active and constructive partner for Ukraine, which is helping to overcome the current difficulties. Europe cannot afford another frozen conflict that destroys stability and poses security risks. The solidarity shown by the European Union in Ukraine is our commitment to continue the project of a united, secure and prosperous Europe.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing.- I vote against.The proposals presented do not appear to be impartial but are instead very biased in favor of Ukraine.The internal conflict that Ukraine is experiencing and the tense relationship that has been created with the neighboring Russian Federation deserved a more careful analysis of the facts and causes, and also of possible solutions.The European Parliament, or rather its disastrous majority made up of PPE-PSE-ALDE, instead of trying to calm the spirits of all the parties involved, throws, in a completely irresponsible way, fuel on the fire, and proposes ... sanctions againstthe Russian Federation (sic!).In this situation, the Russian Federation is a necessary and indispensable partner and must be involved in the negotiations for a peaceful solution to the crisis!

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted for the adoption of the resolution on the situation in Ukraine.I welcome the European Parliament's once again support for the new democratic Ukrainian government and for the peace plan aimed at guaranteeing the unity, sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine.On the other hand, I opposed Amendment No 2 from the Verts / ALE Group, the wording of which does not help to ease the tensions that we all want to see.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - After careful consideration, I voted in favor of the resolution on Ukraine on the basis of the following considerations of the resolution, which I make my own: it is necessary to support the peace plan as an important opportunity for the growth of the entire geopolitical area, considering that the Ukraine continues to face difficult political, socio-economic and security challenges and that the conflict in eastern Ukraine represents a serious obstacle to the country's development and prosperity; on the principle of free self-determination of peoples, it is urgent to underline the fundamental right of the Ukrainian people to free determination of the country's political and economic future and the right to protect themselves, in line with Article 51 of the United Nations Charter; I can only condemn the violence and daily loss of life in eastern Ukraine as well as the destruction of homes and property; I point out the obvious need to initiate a reform of the judiciary capable of helping to restore citizens' trust in justice, for a complete realization of the rule of law. I voted in favor of defending European interests and values ​​and promoting stability, prosperity and democracy in the countries of the European continent.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing.- The complicated and tragic situation created in Ukraine and Crimea does not allow an approach that favors one side or the other, we believe that the only will that matters is that of the peoples.Distinctions based on factions cannot be made, we do not want to make considerations on the basis of a political interest.There are huge economic interests at stake concerning raw materials essential for everyone's life.History has taught us how expensive the price is to pay for people, families, communities when they are divided by a border or by the choice of a language or representation.The scenario we are faced with is confused and polluted by too many interests at stake: we bring back to the center of our attention as an Assembly what really is pre-eminent and what really matters.Citizens and their freedom of choice.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution.Although the EU's powers in this area are rather limited, it is necessary to do everything possible to ensure that international political pressure is such as to induce the parties to seek a peaceful solution to the dispute.It is not easy to judge from the outside, and I do not allow myself to do so, also because when an armed conflict begins both sides have their faults, but I wish there were no wars, especially at the gates of the EU.First lay down your weapons, and then I will be the first to commit myself so that negotiations can take place in order to obtain solutions that please everyone.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have voted against this resolution because it is a blatant act of interference with the country and especially with the regions raised against the fascist coup d'état.This resolution does not make any mention of the responsibility that the European Union has had in the unleashing of violence in the country, an EU complicit in a coup, which supports and encourages neo-Nazi militias in order to gain access to thelong-awaited natural resources, especially gas, necessary for competition with Russia.The equidistance in condemning the violence is a true exercise of cynicism when seeing a powerful army massacre small cities.It is because of this lack of recognition of the responsibility of the EU that I have decided to vote against this resolution.

name: Corina Creţu (S&D)
text: signed up. - The recent air tragedy in eastern Ukraine, which has resulted in the deaths of almost 300 innocent civilians, many of them Europeans, once again demonstrates the need for greater involvement of the European Union in resolving the situation in its immediate vicinity. I therefore voted in favor of the European Parliament adopting the resolution on Ukraine at its plenary session in Strasbourg. It is all the more important to show solidarity with our eastern neighbors and support the way out of this crisis as, by signing the Association Agreement at the end of last month, Ukraine demonstrated not only its attachment to European values, but also its intention. undisguised efforts to build a true democracy. Or achieving this goal is possible only through the existence of a stable political, social and economic foundation, free from the challenges on national security that today, unfortunately, are the order of the day in Ukraine. Moreover, we see how, unrestrained, the armed conflict produces victims of different nationalities, with effects that are also felt internationally. It is also the duty of the European Union to ensure that innocent people do not fall prey to violence and irresponsible acts.

name: Andi-Lucian Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. - This vote comes at a very precise time: Ukraine was the first item debated after the vote on the Commission President. I believe in a strong, united and coherent European Union which is able to address global challenges while protecting the interests of all Europeans. This is what I hope to see in the next five years and this is what I want to see in Ukraine. The EU, its Member States and the G7 partners have expressed their unanimous support for Ukraine's sovereignty, territorial integrity and freedom of choice. The Association Agreement and the clear commitment of the international community constitute an important asset in this delicate transition period to promote economic and political stabilisation and reform in the country. But there can be no peace and stability without an act of responsibility and political maturity on the part of the Russian Federation through: 1. a clear commitment to the implementation of the peace plan; 2. the cessation of all related military activities; 3. a strong stand against illegally armed groups; and 4. a halt to the flow of weapons and militants across the border. The EU must use its full diplomatic weight in this regard.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing.- In view of the worrying instability in Ukraine and its climate of violence, I supported this resolution, which calls for the conflict to be defused.A political solution must be found in the face of this crisis.I support a balanced diplomatic approach in partnership with Russia to emerge from the crisis and ensure the restoration of peace in Ukraine.However, while I welcome the signing by Ukraine, Georgia and Moldova of association agreements with the European Union, I recall my opposition to the establishment of a visa exemption regime as well astheir prospects for joining the European Union.These partner countries are not currently intended to join the European Union.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This resolution seeks to obscure the EU's responsibilities in the current situation in Ukraine. It seeks to hide that it was with the support of the EU, the US and NATO that extreme right-wing forces, admittedly neo-fascists and xenophobes, representing the most reactionary sectors of the Ukrainian oligarchy, consummated a coup and took power. And it is with this support that they remain there. The objectives and nature of the EU's action are reflected in the immediate signing of the Association / Free Trade Area Agreement with the coup government and the agreement with the IMF, which will further aggravate the country's already difficult economic and social situation and of your people. Thus, a coup power was supported that stirred up divisions, instigated violence, the withdrawal of fundamental rights and freedoms, leading to the resistance of broad popular sectors; it is agreed with the attempt to outlaw forces that have a dissenting thought, namely the Communist Party of Ukraine. There are plenty of reasons to reject this resolution. Furthermore, a mystification of the right of self-defense is elaborated, hypocritically invoking the UN Charter and the principles of Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity - principles with which we are in agreement - bleaching and supporting the continuation of the action of the coup forces. .

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing.- The debate on the situation in Ukraine was determined by the unjustifiable and unprecedented absence of Mrs Ashton.My country has a Schengen border with Ukraine, which is why I cannot accept any other activities that our High Representative, Mrs Ashton, has been carrying out during this debate in the plenary of the newly elected EP.There is a civil war in Ukraine, with which we have only recently signed an association agreement, civilians are dying and all fundamental and human rights are being grossly violated.The whole situation in Ukraine has been underestimated by top EU officials from the beginning.It is not clear today how the potential economic and financial losses of EU member states that will provide reverse gas flows to Ukraine will be compensated.Therefore, I cannot support any resolution.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution. The escalation of violence in eastern Ukraine is unacceptable and I believe that we must not remain impassive in the face of these tragic events. President Petro Poroshenko has my full support for the establishment of the peace plan preserving sovereignty, territorial integrity and national unity in Ukraine. Russia must urgently support this plan which will ease tensions in Ukraine and must call for strict respect for the ceasefire. I welcome the Association Agreement between the European Union and Ukraine, which will be a means of launching the political and economic reforms that Ukrainians are eagerly awaiting. This agreement will bring modernization of the country, strengthening of the rule of law and economic growth. Finally, I would like the European Union to be open to dialogue with Russia and to tackle the issue of energy security in particular frankly.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution on the situation in Ukraine as I believe that it is the duty of the European Union to take all possible measures to restore the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine and end the conflict.Russia's annexation of Crimea is an unacceptable action and contrary to all the norms of international law.Europe's response to such an act should be tough and severe economic and financial sanctions.The unity of European leaders in relations with Russia is also crucial, as is sending a clear and coherent signal that Europe will not tolerate border violations and disregard for territorial integrity.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution on Ukraine, which supports initiatives for peace, condemns the ongoing violence in the east of the country and calls on Russia to actively support the cessation of hostilities and thestabilization of Ukraine.I welcome the adoption of this text by a very large majority.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I welcome the fact that, by means of this resolution, the European Parliament has insisted on the urgent need to find a diplomatic and political solution to the Russian-Ukrainian crisis while showing the greatest firmness vis-à-vis Russia by reminding it of its obligations under international law. The European Union must be more present and more visible in this conflict by encouraging all parties to implement the ceasefire immediately, in order to ensure de-escalation. However, I abstained at the time of the final vote for two reasons. Firstly, contrary to what Amendment 7 proposed, I do not consider Ukraine's vocation to join the EU. The EU-Ukraine Association Agreement, signed on June 27, 2014, is in my opinion the most suitable instrument for sustaining the partnership with our Ukrainian neighbors and strengthening our ties. In addition, I did not wish to support paragraph 28 concerning visa liberalization as it stood. In this case, it would have been very appropriate to recall the conclusions of the Foreign Affairs Council of 23 June 2014 which recommended an impact study on the possible effects of such liberalization in terms of migration and security on the EU. .

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution. I would like to especially highlight the importance of paragraph 12 of the EP joint resolution that suggests and supports preparations for introducing further sanctions against Russia, including the economic, financial and energy sectors. It is especially important to immediately apply an arms and dual-use technology embargo, which means a collective ban on the sale of arms to Russia from any Member State, to be maintained until the situation in eastern Ukraine has fully normalised.  I welcome the US Administration taking an important step further by introducing new sanctions covering the financial and energy sector. The EU must follow suit without any further delay. I especially call on the Member States and Council to set an embargo on arms and dual-use technology and a collective ban on the sale of arms to Russia. In the current situation it is absolutely crucial not to provide an aggressor with high-tech weaponry that can be used against Ukraine or possibly also against others in Europe. Therefore I call strongly for a halt to the Mistral deal that would give Russia all the means to attack Ukraine also from the sea.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: in writing. - We will soon commemorate the 75th anniversary of the Ribbentrop-Molotov Pact, when two aggressors divided Europe. It took us 65 years to reverse the effects of this pact in 2004. Let us not divide Europe again, no matter what a sweet proposal comes from Russia - let us not give up on Ukraine. We must clearly and unequivocally demand that Russia withdraw its troops from the Ukrainian border, stop supporting terrorists with weapons and military equipment. The crash of a civilian plane only proves that this conflict is not local. No one can feel safe anymore as long as there are externally backed terrorists in eastern Ukraine. Europe has the political and economic muscles - tougher sanctions, if Russian aggression does not stop, they must be applied. We must talk about the European perspective for Ukraine, I understand that this is a difficult subject for many of you here, but, believe me, it is a matter of life and death for those fighting in Ukraine. These events show that we need to strengthen deeper cooperation not only with our Eastern neighbors, but also with our strategic transatlantic partners, the United States and Canada, who share the same values ​​of freedom and democracy as we do.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: in writing.- We have listened to a long debate.Various arguments were raised, rational and emotional, but dictated by concern for the state of affairs and the dangerous direction of development.I consider the motion for a resolution tabled to be balanced, and at the same time important and fundamentally important.It is evidence of the productive application of the Community method, not the international one.I commend the authors of this resolution.I am pleased with the adoption of this resolution.

name: Paloma López (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have voted against this resolution because it is a blatant act of interference with the country and especially with the regions raised against the fascist coup d'état.This resolution does not make any mention of the responsibility that the European Union has had in the unleashing of violence in the country, an EU complicit in a coup, which supports and encourages neo-Nazi militias in order to gain access to thelong-awaited natural resources, especially gas, necessary for competition with Russia.The equidistance in condemning the violence is a true exercise of cynicism when seeing a powerful army massacre small cities.It is because of this lack of recognition of the responsibility of the EU that I have decided to vote against this resolution.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: written. - I voted in favor of this resolution because I agree with its fundamental thrust, the commitment to democracy, the rule of law and self-determination. However, the following aspects are missing from the resolution: 1. The Crimea was given away in 1954 in an arbitrary state act and without the consent of the predominantly Russian-speaking population. 2. The principle of non-interference in the internal affairs of another state is to be observed by all other states. 3. As far as right-wing extremist groups were involved in the Maidan overthrow, these must be resolutely fought by the Ukrainian government. 4. The right of peoples to self-determination and the right of ethnic groups to strive for a change of state borders in a peaceful way must be respected. 5. A free, fair, democratic referendum is a legitimate expression of the will of the people of a state or region. 6. If the government wants to preserve the territorial integrity of Ukraine, it is obliged to hold talks with those who seek peaceful secession.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution on Ukraine because the situation continues to develop and there has not been an end to the tension between the different sides. This resolution was important in publishing the Parliament’s joint position on this issue and that Members continue to monitor the situation.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This bellicose resolution only aims to aggravate the Ukrainian crisis with the avowed aim of securing this country to Europe and NATO, to the detriment of its sovereignty and economic interests. Without any balance, this text denounces the action of "Russian mercenaries" but in no way condemns the de facto government in place in Kiev, even though it includes several neo-Nazi ministers and it uses armed force against his own people. The attachment of Crimea to Russia voted by a large majority by referendum is denounced as "an annexation". But not a word is spoken to condemn the Odessa massacre, of which Russian-speaking opponents were victims. Finally, the text welcomes the recent signing of the free trade agreement between the EU and Ukraine, which is dangerous for the Ukrainian economy, will permanently compromise the country's unity and attack Russia. I vote resolutely against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing.- The situation in Ukraine worries me especially.I consider it to be a strategic country in Europe, which has been successively damaged by Russia.The EU cannot ignore the escalating military conflict in eastern Ukraine, where Russian soldiers are known to fight Ukrainian forces alongside separatist rebels.There is also an EU-Ukraine Association Agreement and an Agreement on a Comprehensive and Deepened Free Trade Area, signed on 27 June 2014, which must be respected and safeguarded.The EU's foreign policy must be at the forefront of unequivocal support for Ukraine in drawing up a peace plan.I voted in favor of this resolution.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution as it supports Ukraine in preserving its unity, sovereignty and territorial integrity and emphasises the measures to be taken to strengthen political and economic reform and the rule of law. Moreover, it stresses the deep concern over the deteriorating conditions of human rights and the worsening humanitarian situation faced by civilians, activists and journalists.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing.- It was with dismay that I learned of the Malaysia Airlines plane crash (MH17) killing nearly 300 people.All my thoughts are with the families and loved ones of the victims.It is urgent to let the OSCE experts do their work in the greatest freedom in order to clarify the circumstances of this tragedy as quickly as possible.This human catastrophe is pushing for the conclusion of a ceasefire as soon as possible by all parties to the conflict.I strongly condemn the escalation of violence and violations of human rights, especially in eastern Ukraine.Russia must assume its responsibilities and accept a negotiated way out of the crisis, which alone will allow a return to stability.This process should be carried out with respect for the unity, sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. - I support this resolution, which calls on everyone involved to stop the violence and to contribute to finding a lasting political solution. Moreover the resolution calls for additional efforts in the field of anti-discrimination, noting with particular concern the negative attitude towards LGBT and the fact that two right-wing parties of Ukraine openly identify combatting homosexuality as one of their political tasks. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing.- I supported this resolution because the European Union cannot remain a spectator of the situation which is playing out in the east of Ukraine and which is deteriorating day by day.The text offers diplomatic avenues that can improve the situation.However, this crisis once again highlights Europe's lack of significant leadership on the international stage.In 2008, Nicolas Sarkozy, who chaired the European Council, succeeded in stopping the Russian offensive in Georgia.When Europe is embodied and respected, its voice carries.This situation should challenge the Heads of State and Government in the coming weeks when appointing the next European personalities and in particular the High Representative for Foreign Affairs.

name: Massimo Paolucci (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) Mr President, unfortunately I was unable to take part in the vote on the resolution tabled on the current situation in Ukraine. However, I would like to leave a written declaration of mine and an expression of my support for the adopted text on file. After the street clashes of the past months and the bloody tensions with Russia that still exist, today the new Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko finds himself having to face his first and important challenge, which is to reach a ceasefire with the government Russian, to restore a climate of serenity and freely determine the future of their country. I am convinced that the government must have all our support and support. Do not weaken Ukraine's process of association and economic integration with the EU. In this context, I believe that Europe must do more and play a leading role, as unfortunately has not happened up to now. This is why I am confident that the President-elect of the Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, and the future High Representative for Foreign Affairs will work to restore strength to the EU and make it a major player in resolving the crisis, also to avoid any repercussions on the energy supply of the our continent, on which a new and serious reflection needs to be opened.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: in writing. - The KKE is voting against the joint resolution signed by the parties of the monopoly coalition - EPP, Social Democrats, Liberals - together with the Conservatives-Reformers and the Greens. This is a war declaration of the political representatives of capital that demands escalation of the EU-US-NATO imperialist intervention in Ukraine, intensification of their confrontation with capitalist Russia. Openly supports the reactionary government of Ukraine, its murderous military operations in Eastern Ukraine, killing hundreds of civilians, the anti-popular policy jointly pursued by the Ukrainian government, the IMF and the EU. The European Parliament with its resolutions supported and supported the reactionary and fascist organizations, the persecutions unleashed by the government against the communists and the Communist Party of Ukraine. The EU plans to deploy a police-military force in Ukraine to consolidate its position, ensure the penetration and strengthening of EU monopolies, to control the region's vast energy reserves and transport routes, and to find new locations. markets. The Ukrainian people are paying dearly with their blood for the imperialist confrontations, the interests of the monopolies. That is why he must defend his own interests, fighting for his own power, against the domination and power of monopolies.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution calling for an immediate end to the violence in Ukraine.A political solution to this conflict could have avoided the deaths of more than 200 civilians shot down on July 17, 2014, along with their plane, over Ukrainian soil.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted for the resolution on Ukraine a few hours before the probable destruction by a missile of the Malaysian Airlines airliner over eastern Ukraine.This resolution called for a situation of appeasement after the numerous military attacks and the occupation of the territory by pro-Russian separatists.Political and diplomatic tension has risen by several notches and those responsible for this tragic act will have to be brought to international justice.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. - Yesterday, I voted for a resolution calling on the High Representative to step up the deployment of the civilian mission under the common security and defense policy in the security and police sectors. This mission, if it is to really have an impact, must have the necessary means and be provided with an ambitious mandate in order to be able to provide real support to the Ukrainians in the framework of the assiduous efforts that will have to be deployed to stabilize the situation. in the country. The resolution also calls on Russia to show its determination to support the peace plan (the tragedy of the Malaysian airline's plane demonstrating more than ever the absolute urgency to do everything possible to end this conflict). Parliament also asked the Council to impose new sanctions on Russia in the fields of the economy, finance and energy as well as a collective embargo on arms sales in the country. A call that was heard because the Council decided to expand the sanctions linked to the crisis in eastern Ukraine, in particular by adding new names of people and entities, including Russians, to the sanctions list.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have voted against this resolution because it is a blatant act of interference with the country and especially with the regions uprising against the fascist coup d'état.This resolution does not make any mention of the responsibility that the European Union has had in the unleashing of violence in the country, an EU complicit in a coup, which supports and encourages neo-Nazi militias in order to gain access to thelong-awaited natural resources, especially gas, necessary for competition with Russia.Equidistance in condemning violence is a true exercise of cynicism when seeing a powerful army massacre small cities.It is because of this lack of recognition of the responsibility of the EU that I have decided to vote against this resolution.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written.- The most important thing is to mention the signing of an association agreement with Ukraine, which should be a turning point in political life.European money of 11 billion euros needs to be used to stabilize the country and implement reforms.The EU's foreign policy influence in the case of Ukraine should be reflected in respect for European values, but also in the neighborhood enlargement policy, energy policy, but also in relation to the violation of territorial integrity and violation of international law.It is necessary to pursue a clear foreign policy and continue to put pressure and restrictions on Russia.I want to welcome President Poroshenko's peace plan and its most important point, which is Ukraine's right to control its territory.I also want to support the ratification and implementation of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement as soon as possible.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing.- We have prepared a set of new measures, including the freezing of programs in Russia carried out by the European Investment Bank (EIB) and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD).Talks are also underway to "add new names to the list of targeted sanctions."With the worsening situation in Donbass, ample evidence of Russia's involvement in the actions of combatants increasingly gives reason to move to 'phase 3' sanctions in order to oppose theRussian aggression.Russia failed to fulfill the conditions set by the European Council last month to avoid new sanctions that could have a strong impact on its economy.Europe must be strong and uphold democracy on Europe's borders.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I am deeply concerned that the murderous armed conflict in Ukraine has recently shown the signs of its rapid deterioration and internationalization. There are numerous reports that refer to the suffering of the civilian population in the course of military action, which was also confirmed by OSCE monitoring and international human rights organizations. The number of internally displaced persons and refugees is on the rise in Ukraine and neighboring countries.  The situation is on edge of humanitarian catastrophe. Against such background any decision of the EU body shall be based on the principles of the protection of human rights, international humanitarian law and European values. EU shall be even more demanding dealing with those who claim to share with us European values. In the resolution there is a clear demand to all parties of the conflict to rectify the poor situation of the civilian population, to respect international humanitarian law and international human rights law.   However, in general the text is unbalanced and may leave an impression that EU is taking sides in the armed conflict where all parties shall be objects of principled criticism. Several important allegations in the document are not sufficiently substantiated.  Therefore I did not find it possible to vote in support of this resolution.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I have added my name to this resolution as I firmly believe that full respect for democracy is the tool to achieve what the Ukrainians want. Hence, I welcome any initiative towards stopping the violence that is gravely affecting the country and its population. Furthermore, as clearly stated in the resolution, it is in the interest of all parties that the well-being of its people is promoted through different measures such as political agreements, including free trade agreements with third countries, and applying best practices to its government policies.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have voted against this resolution because it is a blatant act of interference with the country and especially with the regions uprising against the fascist coup d'état.This resolution does not make any mention of the responsibility that the European Union has had in the unleashing of violence in the country, an EU complicit in a coup, which supports and encourages neo-Nazi militias in order to gain access to thelong-awaited natural resources, especially gas, necessary for competition with Russia.Equidistance in condemning violence is a true exercise of cynicism when seeing a powerful army massacre small cities.It is because of this lack of recognition of the responsibility of the EU that I have decided to vote against this resolution.

name: Jarosław Leszek Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have lent my support to the Motion for a Resolution on the situation in Ukraine. From the beginning of this dire situation I have supported Ukraine in its situation with Russia. I strongly believe that the EU must provide all the help and assistance necessary to protect Ukraine from the sphere of influence of Russia and Mr Putin. I feel that as a sovereign State it is the Ukrainians who must determine their future, not Russia, nor the EU.  In recent months we have witnessed the chaos that has engulfed the country and since then there have been some very positive steps forward such as the election of the new President and the recent signing of a trade agreement between Ukraine and the EU. The EU must continue to strengthen its relations with Ukraine and assist in any way it can with the security of energy sources as this will be a vital part of developing and sustaining an economically sound Ukraine, as well as assisting in the desperately needed modernisation of its infrastructure.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing.- I welcome and support the resolution adopted on Ukraine.I am very pleased that this Parliament has been able to adopt a clear text and support the Ukrainian Government's efforts to preserve the country's territorial unity.At the same time, I think that the Slovak government's action on the issue of the reverse gas flow agreement deserved not a compliment, but a sharp rebuke.The Slovak government is taking steps to increase the risk that in the winter months we will have to deal with a crisis in the supply of heat to the people of Ukraine.Here, too, we see that the high energy dependence of Slovakia and other new member states of the Union on Russian gas is not only an economic but also a political problem that we must solve together.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR). -
text: Mister President!I wanted to explain my vote on it.I rejected this resolution because it does not take into account the essential point of distortion of competition within the European Union, namely the fact that the common currency has massively hindered the competitiveness of the southern European countries in particular and, in connection with this hindrance to competitiveness, unemployment and in particularYouth unemployment has arisen.This major obstacle to economic development should also have been pointed out.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE). -
text: Youth unemployment is reaching alarming proportions in some Member States, and the consequences of this phenomenon may not be measurable today.Today's problems of young people will have an impact on the demographic processes of the coming years, employment problems have intensified internal migration in the European Union, and the financing of large social welfare systems has also become difficult.The EU can only encourage, support and help the process, it will not be able to change the employment situation of young people without the authorities of the Member States.The engines of European economic life are small and medium-sized enterprises.Today, a major and general reduction in red tape would be the greatest help that Member States could give to these companies, which would make it easier for them to employ young workers in accordance with the rules.

name: Anne Sander (PPE). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favor of this resolution because, with nearly 23% unemployed, those under 25 are the main victims of the crisis and of our sluggish growth.This lack of recovery feeds a disenchantment with Europe.Indeed, how can we believe in the European project when it no longer offers prospects?The Youth Employment Initiative is a start, but it affects only one in five regions in my own constituency.However, all these regions suffer from worrying unemployment which tends to be prolonged.I come from a border region and I can tell you that the potential for cross-border jobs is still too untapped.We must develop the EURES mobility program, we must promote multilingualism and we must promote double degrees.Mr President, Europe must bet on this new generation.

name: Joëlle Mélin (NI). -
text: Mr President, our vote had to be negative. The "youth employment" dossier is the symbol of the stinging failure of the supranational utopia. 25% of those under 25 unemployed in Europe, 60% in Greece, two million young Poles exiled in 10 years. Our institution would have liked the unemployment of young people, poorly or poorly trained, to be a variable for adjusting the profits of unscrupulous employers or faceless shareholders, and that the vital forces of each country were inactivated by uprooting, that 'she wouldn't have done it any other way. Indeed, our young people are indeed one of the privileged targets of the economic war unfolding in Europe. Forced displacement and pauperization are proof of this. It is clear that many decisions taken in this chamber over decades have played a role: structural funds from our taxes, misused; projects unsuited to the objectives and therefore ineffective; sterilizing macroeconomic, monetary and normative policies; immigration regulations imposed on nation states, the list goes on. The professional and societal future of young people is primarily a matter of national sovereignty.

name: Tiziana Beghin (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, despite the suggestions of my group - first of all the request for a derogation from the 3% limit for investments in favor of young people - have not even been taken into consideration at the behest of the big parties in this Parliament, theThe 5-star movement that I represent at the moment still considered the final text valid, acceptable, and therefore decided to support it.Colleagues, the message that I want to leave you at this moment is very simple.We think it does not matter where the ideas come from, as long as they are good and are in favor of the citizens who have called us here to represent you.We have applied and will always apply this principle.I hope that what I have said will inspire the work of the commissions in the future.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I supported the adoption of this Resolution on Youth Employment in order to finally, seriously and effectively encourage the solution of one of the biggest problems in the European Union today, which is high youth unemployment.The most alarming situation is in the south of Europe, and the Republic of Croatia has also not been spared the difficulties caused by the economic crisis, which has unfortunately been most felt by young people on the threshold of their working life.As much as one third of the unemployed in the Republic of Croatia are young people between 15 and 29 years of age.Young people also go to other countries in Croatia because they cannot exercise their right to work in the Republic of Croatia, and the right to work is a human right, and if it is not guaranteed to everyone, then it is the result of the wrong policy.I welcome the call from the Resolution for effective control of the implementation of the Youth Guarantee, because of the 6 billion euros so far, almost nothing has been spent in the member states of the European Union, and the problem still exists.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the reduction of youth unemployment is one of the most important challenges to be faced in the coming years as it affects all the countries of the Union and, in some of them, youth unemployment rates have reached worrying and desperate levels. Many young people cannot find work and for this reason they are forced to emigrate. With respect to this serious situation which also involves my country, Italy, the new European Commission will be responsible for presenting a recovery plan to launch investment policies aimed at creating jobs and stabilizing employment. The Youth Guarantee is certainly helping states to face the serious employment crisis, but it is not and cannot be decisive. Structured actions will be needed to relaunch the economy and development to encourage the emergence of new jobs. It will be necessary to resort to flexibility in the use of public funds, without which it is difficult to start growth. The resolution in its final text goes in this direction and that is why I voted in favor.

name: Elena Ethel Schlein (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favor of the resolution even though I would have preferred to hear even stronger words on this issue which in my country, Italy, sees youth unemployment in some regions as high as 60%. It is a good thing that this resolution is asking for an extension of the Youth Guarantee up to thirty years. I'm 29 and I don't think we should have peace as long as there are my peers to whom I still hear: I would like to have a child but I can't find the courage because I don't know how to support it. It is also good that more resources are being asked to invest in this program, and I think we should strongly insist on this with the Commission. Furthermore, I would have liked to hear stronger words against precariousness, because it is not only a question of what jobs we can create for young people, but also of being able to create quality jobs in the finally direction of a sustainable future, therefore in a direction that I think is what we must feel as a responsibility towards the new generations. Not only what kind of jobs we create, but finally the direction towards a sustainable future, jobs with investments towards an enhancement of the environment, culture and research.

name: Lara Comi (PPE). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favor because the youth unemployment figures are alarming to say the least and require all of our joint efforts, without any political color, precisely because this is one of the priorities.I am absolutely convinced that giving job opportunities to our young people means building their future and also our future.Young people are the freshest workforce in our society and above all they represent the most fertile ground to cultivate.A collaborative strategy and truly integrated actions, because this is what we are missing.An integration between the European Union and the Member States must be the best solution.The Guarantee Fund is fine.In Italy it has been extended up to 29 years, an important step but must also be taken in the other Member States.And from this we must start with the harmonization of the Bologna process, otherwise any effort will be useless.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I wanted to say that I voted in favor on this issue, but I emphasize that I have a strong reservation about what has been said here and what is also written in that document.I do not just want to give money to address these issues in the short term, that is, to create jobs for young people, but I want them to be addressed systematically, that is, in the long term, using examples of good practice, for example in Austria, Germany orSwitzerland, where a dual education system operates.Countries that have not been involved in the education of young people for a long time and systematically have problems with high unemployment rates in this group today.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE). -
text: I am not in favor of measures that are closely targeted at one segment of society.Especially not when we are talking about a problem such as unemployment.I understand why we want to address youth employment as a matter of priority, but I would like to remind you that we should prioritize solutions that strengthen solidarity between the generations.Family business support meets this requirement.Because working in a family business not only gives young people important skills and experience, but also learns responsibility and business ethics under parental supervision.It was its lack that led us to the financial crisis.Therefore, I would like the Commission to present an analysis of the business environment with regard to family business and to propose legislation that would simplify the creation of family businesses and take into account their specific problems.

name: Steven Woolfe (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, this amendment was proposed by the ECR Group and supported by the British Conservative Party. It accepted the principle that the EU should have free movement of workers but it supported only qualified free movement. This shows how half-hearted the British Conservative Party is. This is qualified euroscepticism. Mass open-door immigration has resulted in lower wage and employment levels in the UK and throughout Europe. We abstained because we believe that nation states should have exclusive control of their borders. There should not be qualified free movement of workers; there should be controlled migration, open to the whole world, using a points-based system and managed by the nation states, not the EU.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I have not been able to vote in favor of this resolution because, despite containing some points that I consider of extreme interest to solve the very serious situation that the youth of the European Union are going through, it does not hold the Member States responsible for this situation. Many governments in southern European states are trying to expel their youth as a way to reduce the social unrest that they are experiencing due to the imposition of austerity policies. However, the resolution contains positive points when it appeals to the need to reduce inequalities, the relaxation of the rules of the European Social Fund so that projects are carried out, recognizes the scarcity of resources allocated to the Youth Employment Initiative, etc. However, this resolution is insufficient for the main problem facing the European economy and that is why I have not been able to vote in its favor. These funds represent a band-aid on a gunshot wound.

name: Andrus Ansip (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution on youth employment because I consider it particularly necessary to move the age limit for participants in youth unemployment measures from 24 to 30.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. - In Italy, 1 in 10 people live in absolute poverty, 700,000 young people between the ages of 15-24 are unemployed and risk marginalization. Is this the Europe that our children deserve? If for President Junker unemployment in Italy is “the fault of the Italians”, for me the problems of the European unemployed, especially young people, are two and are called the single market and the euro. Wages cut to the bone and wild competition from those EU member countries that take advantage of an injunction and wrong system. Europe stop scrambling for mirrors and acknowledge that it has failed! Its insane policies of hospitality and income redistribution have saturated our labor market and sent welfare systems into a tailspin to give priority to the newcomers. What remains is record-breaking unemployment and weak categories, such as young and old, without services and without support. Europe must change the rules of the game and focus on competitiveness. We need equal tax and social security rules for everyone, a block on tourism for benefits and restitution of monetary sovereignty to countries that want to leave the euro. Otherwise, Europe risks exploding, destroying the hope and the future of the new generations.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have abstained.The proposed resolution highlights youth unemployment and the enormous problems it creates in the EU today.It emphasizes the importance of combating youth unemployment as an investment in the future.I agree with that.But the resolution does not mark out the austerity policy as the main cause of the extremely high youth unemployment.It should also more clearly emphasize the importance of an expansive economic policy that, with green investment and enhanced welfare, creates employment and works for gender equality and social justice.In addition, I oppose the demand for new supranational legislation in paragraph 3 and the demand for reduced corporate taxes in paragraph 43. That is why I abstained.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: written. - Youth employment is one of our top priorities. There are 120 million Europeans below the poverty line and 25% of the more than 25 million unemployed are young. In my country, Spain, more than 50% of young people are without work. Youth employment will define the EU for the next generation. The full development of the Youth Guarantee is the central element of the socialist strategy of job creation. We are committed to substantially increasing your budget and extending it up to the age of 30. We must also introduce decent minimum wages for all, guarantee equal pay and the protection of the rights of workers, trade unions, social dialogue and anti-discrimination legislation. We want to end social dumping and review the Directive on posting of workers to improve their protection. We want a more ambitious industrial policy, support the social economy and SMEs, promote technological and sustainable innovation, and improve economic performance. The challenges are many. At the socialist request, some of our demands were recognized yesterday in his government program by the new President of the European Commission. We will remain vigilant in fulfilling your commitments to our Group.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution because it draws the European Parliament's attention to the problems of young people: high unemployment and increased poverty among young people. I am one of the authors of this resolution. Data provided by the European Commission show that in 2012 as many as a third of all young people in Europe are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. This is due to deep-rooted discrimination against young people in the workplace across Europe. Even after getting a job, young people are discriminated against and even exploited, often facing so-called ‘in-work poverty’. Even after getting a job, young people are discriminated against and even exploited. That is why statistics on poverty and social exclusion among young people are so unjustifiably high in our rich and secure Europe. Young people also need job security, social protection and social guarantees. The EU Charter of Fundamental Rights enshrines the right to social security for all, not only for experienced workers, but also for newcomers.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: signed up. - Youth unemployment is a major issue that every EU Member State should be increasingly concerned about, given that almost a quarter of young Europeans do not currently have a job. I voted in favor of the resolution on combating youth unemployment because I am aware of the need to create new jobs, the need to reconcile the demands of employers with the knowledge gained in school by young people and to stimulate job-generating investment and entrepreneurship among young people. All this represents investment in a competitive and prosperous European future, to which we can successfully contribute. Specifically, there are tools at European level to prevent and reduce youth unemployment. We need a European framework to encourage temporary employment that could contribute to the integration of young people into the labor market. Increasing the mobility of young people should be extended to programs aimed at unskilled work. I am convinced that programs such as setting up a young farmer or Erasmus for young entrepreneurs can play a multiple role. At the same time, it contributes to increasing employment, improving performance and supporting free initiative.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing.- Voting of abstention.The proposals presented are nothing more than "catalogs of good intentions", where there is a shortage of real and concrete proposals to tackle a crisis in youth work that has not been seen since the second post-war period.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of the resolution on youth employment calling for more effective measures, including common minimum standards for apprenticeships and decent wages. Youth unemployment has reached unprecedented levels, with a European average of 23% and peaks of over 50% in some Member States. In total 5.3 million European citizens under the age of 25 are unemployed. Therefore I think that the European funding of employment programs should be increased in future annual budgets. Furthermore, I think the Commission should closely monitor the implementation of the 'Youth Guarantee' launched last year and propose European minimum standards on the quality of traineeships, wage levels and access to employment services. Community funding for the "Youth Guarantee", currently 6 billion euros, must also be increased. In addition, I advise Member States to give priority to teaching science, technology, engineering and mathematics, as these profiles are likely to be the most in demand on the labor market. Finally, to encourage job creation, I call on national governments to reduce administrative burdens for self-employed, micro and small and medium-sized enterprises and introduce tax policies capable of creating a favorable climate for private investment.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. - Austerity policies have turned out to be disastrous from many points of view, but what is worrying at a structural and long-term level is the tragedy of unemployment. The percentages on the youth level are alarming to say the least and create a deficit in terms of production and welfare that cannot be bridged. To pay the price will be the future generations who will have to make sacrifices to support those in their families who have not been able to accumulate enough to be entitled to a pension. If we look at the data as a whole, we discover that this gap is not only alarming for the 18-29 age group but becomes even more serious when we consider long-term unemployment for the 30-60 age group. They are people who, unlike young workers, see their chances of finding a new job reduced and therefore create that pension gap described above. Considering the accumulation of these enormous problems, one can no longer hesitate to give relief and support from the states in order not to condemn more than two generations to continuous precariousness.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. - Since the onset of the economic crisis youth unemployment has become a serious problem in the EU where 23.6 % of our youth are now unemployed, which is almost double the adult rate. In Ireland our youth unemployment rate is 23.7 %; this, combined with the mass emigration, equates to a lost generation. A stronger commitment and improved monitoring are needed from Member States to improve the situation of young people. Jobs are not just about money for our youth, they are also about dignity and self-worth. Our young people need access to quality jobs that respect their rights, including the right to stability and security through a job that has a decent and fair wage, social protection and enables a secure life of dignity and autonomy. The Youth Guarantee needs to be to be monitored effectively and we need to be updated regularly on its progress.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing.- This crisis has been going on for too long and is eroding the wealth gained over decades of work.To get out of this, we must certainly focus on priorities, including the recovery of employment.We all agree on this, but there is a further step to take: segmenting the workforce by age group.The 60-year-old who has lost his job must be offered the possibility of supplementing his contributions in order to retire;the forty-year-old must be offered retraining and new opportunities;the twenty year old must be given the opportunity to train his own professionalism and experience, in the absence of which in ten years the twenty year olds of that time will be in competition with the twenty year olds of today and the job market will implode.This is why I voted in favor of this resolution: because, without taking anything away from those who are no longer young, I believe it is far-sighted to think of young people and, at the same time, to take action on others.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I have not been able to vote in favor of this resolution because, despite containing some points that I consider interesting to solve the very serious situation that the youth of the European Union are going through, it does not consider austerity policies as the main cause of this situation of the European Union and the Troika, nor the responsibility of the Member States. Many Governments of the Southern European States are trying to expel their young people as a way to reduce the social unrest they go through due to the imposition of the policies of austerity. However, the resolution contains positive points when it appeals to the need to reduce inequalities, the relaxation of the rules of the European Social Fund so that projects are carried out, recognizes the scarcity of resources allocated to the Youth Employment Initiative, etc. However, this resolution is insufficient for the main problem facing the European economy and that is why I have not been able to vote in its favor. These funds represent a band-aid on a gunshot wound.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing.- I am firmly convinced of the insufficiency of what has been done so far to put a stop to the continuing increase in youth unemployment rates.We said it some time ago and we repeat it today: resources are scarce and badly used.We need to find the courage to change formulas: enough external professional training, which only contributes to serving the interests of the companies that carry it out, without guaranteeing any added value.We make sure that the companies themselves train on the job, simplifying the transition between the two phases of the path.The European Social Fund will be fundamental in the coming years, let us ensure that we do not waste it and do not waste the only resources at our disposal.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: signed up.- I believe that, in the context of the current economic crisis, education, training and creativity are essential to ensure innovation, productivity and growth in Europe.I believe in the importance of the Erasmus for All program and welcome the European Commission's position to encourage the resolution of the gap between the Member States in terms of educational standards and the full recognition of diplomas throughout the European Union.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing.- This resolution calling for the revival of youth employment is the pledge that the European Parliament wishes to respect the commitments made during the last European elections.Youth unemployment in Europe is at appalling rates.It is essential for the European Union to take action to invest in education and training.Europe needs a new environment for job creation.It seems to me essential in particular to continue to promote a framework favorable to SMEs, which concentrate the vast majority of jobs within the European Union.By encouraging young entrepreneurs to create SMEs, employment and growth will be revived.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Youth unemployment in the EU reaches an impressive 23%. In some countries, such as Greece and Spain, more than half of young people are unemployed. Portugal is no better, despite the recurring statistical manipulations, aiming to obnubilate that the slight statistical decrease in unemployment is due to the bleeding of emigration, the growing number of young people who are forced to leave the country, a situation that is only paralleled in the black years of the fascism. On the other hand, the jobs created have precarious employment links, substituting work with rights for work without rights. Any resolution that, in fact, had the real intention of changing the current state of affairs would have to demand a break with the main EU economic policies responsible for creating unemployment - which is not done here. In the joint resolution, supported by the right and social democracy, the EU-IMF programs are not mentioned as causing the massive destruction of jobs and the weakening of social and labor rights. Nor is the responsibility for policies embodied in Economic Governance, the European Semester and the Budget Treaty. Omitting this central issue in such a matter of concern is the same as masking the problem, laundering responsibilities. We will not contribute to this hypocritical exercise.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing.- Youth employment is one of the most critical policies in the EU.It is the result of many unconceptual measures, such as raising the retirement age, job losses due to the effects of the economic crisis, but also the absent education system in the Member States.And it is the high level of youth unemployment that is one of the main reasons why the EC and the Council should start considering the harmonization of social policies within the EU.I support the present resolution because it deals at least in part with the situation of youth unemployment through the implementation of the Youth Guarantee program.However, this is not the only solution and a profound structural reform of education will be needed.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: in writing.- On Thursday morning, I voted in favor of recommendations on tackling youth unemployment in Europe.The European Union cannot be satisfied with the youth guarantee alone.It is urgent to take measures to stimulate, among other things, support for SMEs, entrepreneurship, the fight against failure at school, youth mobility or even the establishment of a European framework to ensure the quality ofinternships and apprenticeships.I wanted to emphasize the need to better adapt national education systems to the needs of the labor market.I insist on better recognition of skills and abilities acquired outside formal education, through internships, volunteering, or social work.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: in writing.- Youth unemployment has reached 22% in the European Union, and in some countries it is already around 50%.There is a greater need for direct EU support, and instruments such as the European Youth Guarantee may be appropriate instruments in this regard.The Hungarian example can serve as a model for Europe in tackling unemployment, as youth unemployment has fallen in Hungary thanks to the Workplace Protection Action Plan launched in 2012 and the START program.I voted in favor of the development of a dual vocational training system, the transformation of the higher education system towards real subjects, the creation of a new SME-friendly environment, and the widespread support of professional experience and training.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: in writing. - Every fifth young European is unemployed. This unusually high level of youth unemployment is a complex problem that we must address in a comprehensive manner. I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on this issue as I believe it highlights the most relevant issues for resolving this problem. Firstly, every effort should be made to ensure that the Youth Guarantee funds support the necessary reforms in the Member States. We need a better link between education and the labor market in order to equip young people with the skills that employers are looking for, in particular by promoting good quality internships and apprenticeships in the workplace. Guarantees are a valuable program and I agree with the recommendation that Member States extend their coverage to people up to the age of 30. Second, we must focus on entrepreneurship. As a result of the crisis, many companies were liquidated, while others were forced to reduce employment. That is why I believe that a business-friendly climate should be created and their confidence in the markets rebuilt, which will translate into creating new jobs by them. Incentives to start new businesses should also be created by removing bureaucratic barriers and financial support for start-ups in the form of tax relief, loans and subsidies.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: in writing. - Meeting for the second time since its installation, the European Parliament has chosen to send a strong message to citizens: youth employment is the priority work of this legislature and elected officials will not relax their efforts to fight against endemic unemployment which affects more than five million young people under 25 in Europe, including 22.5% in France. However, if I agree with the diagnosis and the priorities, I regret that these words are not followed by action. Let us not forget that citizens judge Europe by its results and not by its incantatory speeches. But Europe is first and foremost the nations that make and break it. European funding and instruments exist but in reality, it is the Member States, through the economic and employment policies they choose, which have the real power to reverse this curve and to give hope to more young people. in addition disoriented.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the youth employment resolution.It was essential that one of the first texts adopted by Parliament deal with this subject when one in four young people is unemployed in Europe.The situation is critical, and we must act quickly.In particular, we need to make full use of the Youth Guarantee and follow its implementation very closely.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I am pleased that the European Parliament has supported by a large majority the joint resolution aimed at promoting youth employment. The youth unemployment rate has indeed reached unprecedented levels. In March 2014, in the European Union, 5.340 million young people under the age of 25 were unemployed. The European Union must provide answers to this extremely worrying situation. To this end, this resolution encourages the implementation of a strategy for the re-industrialization of Europe as well as a European framework favorable to SMEs. It invites Member States to use the financial instruments offered to them by the European Union, in particular the Youth Guarantee. It also encourages them to adopt preventive actions against early dropping out of studies, to encourage technical education, apprenticeship and entrepreneurship, to invest in the sectors of the future such as digital, telecommunications and infrastructure. energy and promote cross-border employment.

name: Γεώργιος Κατρούγκαλος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- I voted against the resolution because it adopts essentially the same neoliberal view of the EU policies that have led to rising unemployment, rising inequalities and the escalation of the crisis.Only the overthrow of austerity policies and the adoption of development policies, with an emphasis on protecting the weakest social groups and young people, can be a way out of the crisis.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the youth employment resolution, which proposes a series of solutions to the problem of youth unemployment, which is now reaching levels that threaten the development and integrity of Europe. The key issue is to use proven solutions from EU countries, such as the dual-track vocational education system in Germany, where youth unemployment is 7.5% with the EU average over 23%. In Greater Poland, where solutions similar to those in Germany are applied, the unemployment level is one of the lowest in the country. Therefore, the postulate of developing vocational training, the system of recognition of qualifications and the European qualifications framework is crucial for increasing the chances of young people to work. Revision of the education systems in the EU, strengthening of vocational training, as well as programs increasing mobility - international student exchange, apprenticeships and internships should lead to a gradual reduction of youth unemployment. The EU should also focus on supporting entrepreneurship, and in particular on creating a favorable environment for small and medium-sized enterprises, which employ 67% of all employees and generate 85% of new jobs. Therefore, I support the proposals in the resolution to "improve cooperation between business and the education sector at all levels in order to better adapt curricula to the needs of the labor market". I also agree that the amount of EUR 6 billion earmarked for these purposes is insufficient and should be revised to ensure that the actions taken are carried out adequately effectively.

name: Κωνσταντίνα Κούνεβα (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- Regarding my vote in the resolution on youth employment, I would like to emphasize the following: despite the existence of some positive provisions in the text of the resolution, as a whole it remains another wish list and does not promote realistic solutions.In addition, there are several provisions with unclear content, such as paragraphs 2, 4, 42. Still, the constant invocation of entrepreneurship is seen as a "cure" for tackling unemployment, which is not a feasible and realistic answer to the high youth unemployment.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: in writing.- Youth unemployment is still a particularly high and difficult problem in EU countries, which is why I voted in favor of the resolution.The document not only describes in detail the youth unemployment situation in the EU countries, but also provides specific recommendations to the EU member states, the implementation of which I believe would significantly improve the unemployment situation.Particular attention should be paid, I think, to the fact that in 2012small and medium-sized enterprises accounted for as much as 66.5% in the EU.jobs in Europe, so EU countries must provide favorable legal and financial opportunities for such companies to set up and grow.It is also necessary to create favorable conditions for the creation and development of new innovative businesses.

name: Jérôme Lavrilleux (PPE)
