text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution on youth employment.This text aims to remind European heads of state that the fight against youth unemployment must be a priority.The budget and the measures announced must not remain mere communication effects, to the aid of majorities in difficulty.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the resolution on youth employment because it recognizes youth deprived of a future and calls for strong action from the European Union for youth employment. This joint resolution underlines the intolerable levels for young people of unemployment (23% of unemployed young people), precariousness and impoverishment (30% of 15-29 people at risk of poverty or social exclusion). Therefore it requires real efforts in education, training, in order to invest in our youth. It is not satisfied with the 6 billion euros allocated by the Youth Guarantee and is asking, as I did in my speech, for more funds for this program, the needs of which the International Labor Organization has estimated at 21 billion. This text also calls for the establishment of minimum standards for young people and a European framework for internships, which I support while calling for even stronger European rules to secure the path of all young people to employment. . This resolution also deals with the economic environment for young people by calling for a necessary stimulation of growth, a reindustrialization of our territories and a determined fight against inequalities. This is why I supported and co-signed this text.

name: Paloma López (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I have not been able to vote in favor of this resolution because, despite containing some points that I consider of extreme interest to solve the very serious situation that the youth of the European Union are going through, it does not hold the Member States responsible for this situation. Many governments in southern European states are trying to expel their youth as a way to reduce the social unrest they are experiencing due to the imposition of austerity policies. However, the resolution contains positive points when it appeals to the need to reduce inequalities, the relaxation of the rules of the European Social Fund so that projects are carried out, recognizes the scarcity of resources allocated to the Youth Employment Initiative, etc. However, this resolution is insufficient for the main problem facing the European economy and that is why I have not been able to vote in its favor. These funds represent a band-aid on a gunshot wound.

name: Monica Luisa Macovei (PPE)
text: in writing. - I welcome the Commissionʼs initiative for a Youth Guarantee scheme which aims to reduce the high figures of unemployment among young people. In March 2014, 5 340 million young persons (under 25) were unemployed in the EU-28, i.e. 10.4 %. This worrying percentage proves the necessity of tackling more effectively integration of youth into the labour market. I join my colleagues in calling on the Member States to support and promote reforms and mechanisms to actively combat youth unemployment and to provide more opportunities for jobs. The Commission has to monitor the implementation of the national Youth Guarantee Plans in each Member State in order to strengthen and reaffirm commitments at national and European level to stimulate youth employment. Additionally, I echo this Resolutionʼs call for the need to reform education and training standards for young people in order to increase their employability and life opportunities. We have a moral responsibility to provide the new generations with support to find their way in the labour market and to work together to combat the damaging effects of the financial crisis on youth employment.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because Youth Employment remains the single biggest challenge for the European Parliament in this new mandate. My Socialist colleagues and I are seeking to change the austerity agenda of the centre-right to the growth-focused agenda of the Socialists. Europe cannot afford to have another lost generation and we must get all of our young people back to good quality employment.

name: Anthea McIntyre (ECR)
text: in writing. - Conservative MEPs fully support initiatives designed to help young people, whatever their circumstances, enter the labour market. The ECR resolution highlighted unemployment, particularly youth unemployment, as the biggest social challenge facing Europe. Conservative MEPs believe that at the national level, it is essential to give education and training systems greater relevance to labour market needs.  Blanket EU laws or initiatives are impractical and inefficient. Actions to tackle youth unemployment are better if they are delivered by national governments. We cannot support calls for new legally binding instruments at EU level, which add little or no value in terms of getting young people into employment. It is not the role of the European Parliament to instruct Member States on how to organise their social security systems.  While we understand the potential for migration to help some young people find work, and while we support the principle of free movement of workers in the EU – this must be qualified. Free movement should be about work, where individuals can follow opportunities and contribute to the host economy rather than moving to take advantage of welfare regimes in other Member States. For these reasons we cannot support the Joint Motion for Resolution.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- This resolution on youth unemployment in Europe is honest about the findings but weak on the solutions.In March 2014, unemployment affected 5,340,000 young people under 25 in the EU, ie an unemployment rate of 23%.The resolution recognizes that the 6 billion euros allocated to the Youth Employment Initiative are not enough and calls for the extension of the youth guarantee up to 30 years.But for the rest, the proposed solutions belong to the liberal register.As always, it is a question of increasing “labor mobility within the Union” and promoting entrepreneurship, even though the main cause of unemployment for young and old alike is'austerity.I vote against.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament's resolution on youth employment, so that measures to combat youth unemployment are reinforced.The European Parliament has called on the Commission to propose a European legal framework with minimum standards for the implementation of guarantees for youth with regard, for example, to the quality of internships, decent wages for young people and access to employment services.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. - The aim of this resolution is to guarantee the effective and coherent implementation of the European Commission’s Youth Guarantee Programme, reiterating the measures to be taken for Europe to have an active, comprehensive and integrated labour market policy with special measures for young people. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I am seriously concerned about the difficulties of finding or keeping a job. I do not forget poverty, unemployment, or the financial obstacles that stand in the face of a young couple wishing to own their home ... But there is one evidence that no one can dispute: it is businesses that create employment and wealth to finance quality public services to citizens. The economic recovery in favor of employment must be sustained. Today, to boost the economy, it is above all important to stimulate productive investment, especially in our small and medium-sized enterprises. SMEs are the largest employers in Europe. SMEs represent over 99% of companies and employ over 90 million people in Europe. They also represent more than 67% of jobs in the private sector (two out of three jobs in the private sector) and more than 58% of the Union's total turnover. With regard to youth employment, which is one of my priorities, I insist on strengthening the “Youth Guarantee” which aims to offer young people a job, a return to studies, training or retraining within a period. 4 months from the end of their schooling.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. - In May 2014, youth unemployment in the European Union reached 22.2%, with more than 5 million people without a professional occupation. Although homologously the unemployment rate has been decreasing, I believe that these are still too high values ​​and a social scourge that needs to be resolved. The European Union approved a Youth Guarantee Program with a budget of € 8 billion a year ago and the Erasmus + Program with a budget of € 14.7 billion. More than 23 billion are available to support young Europeans who must be geared towards reforming the EURES employment platform, supporting companies in terms of hiring and further improving the academic qualifications of the new generations. It is essential for European leaders to listen to the ideas and proposals that young people advocate for their own future. I support the creation of a European platform that integrates the main political, social and economic movements of European youth. Finally, I believe that it is time to promote genuine European mobility programs, thereby increasing employment opportunities for young people in most of the 28 Member States.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution because there is an urgent need to focus on the fight against youth unemployment, which continues to increase month by month. This resolution goes in the right direction since it includes an entire section on education and vocational training. When I was Minister of Apprenticeship and Vocational Training in France, I put in place important policies intended to develop work-study training, which we know can provide young people with a better entry into the labor market. the job market. In fact, 80% of young people who have completed work-study training find a job within 6 months. The fight against youth unemployment can only be done in tune with economic realities. This is why I supported the passages specifically aimed at SMEs which are fundamental sources of employment in Europe. The European Union has a young guarantee of 6 billion, the States must fully commit and define precise objectives. I am aware that national policies to combat youth unemployment must be powerful levers, in particular by developing apprenticeship. It is this orientation that the European Union must develop.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. - The motion for a resolution approved today contains important and above all concrete indications, addressed to the Member States, to combat youth unemployment. In addition to the proposal to extend the Youth Guarantee, both in terms of funding and of the age necessary to take advantage of it, an important exhortation to make efforts that facilitate, rather than limit, the free movement and mobility of workers within the 'Union. In this regard it would be useful to take further into consideration Commissioner Andor's proposal relating to the creation of a "European Unemployment Insurance" and possibly extend it to the structuring of a real "European unitary contract", the same in all Member States, which simplifies to the maximum the mobility of workers guaranteeing the portability of contributions and seniority. I believe it is equally important to emphasize the availability and quality of training and retraining paths for young people, which Member States should implement as soon as possible in order to reduce the enormous inequalities in education that exist between countries but also within of individual national borders.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: written. - Where there are no jobs, none can be guaranteed. So much for a guarantee that the state could neither guarantee nor should it adhere to. It is necessary to rethink EU monetary and fiscal policy to tackle this problem of job creation and discrimination against young job seekers. Equally counterproductive are the goals for 2020, for example, which provide for an academic rate of 40%. Why do we need so many academics? The consequences: more unemployment, sociologists as taxi drivers, lawyers as waiters and an inflation of diplomas. Rather, we need an upgrading of the craft, combined with competencies in the core technologies, qualified skilled workers for our industry and a dual training system, as Austria and Germany are known to dictate. Instead, a guarantee with 6 billion euros is created - too little to achieve an economic effect, too much not to hurt. Because it is only a 6 billion euro show effect for the election campaigns in France and Italy - as expected, it had no impact on youth unemployment rates. Politicians have to concentrate on what they can really influence: the framework conditions surrounding business and training. That is why I voted against the motion for a resolution which seeks to achieve the impossible with the unsuitable.

name: Massimo Paolucci (S&D)
text: in writing. - Unfortunately, I was unable to participate in the vote on the resolution on youth employment, but I chose to leave my written declaration and the expression of my support for the adopted text on record. Finally, the European Union has equipped itself with an instrument such as the Youth Employment Initiative which, although with obvious limits in terms of allocated resources, allows Member States to provide young people between 15 and 24 years of age with training opportunities and working. It is vitally important, however, that the maximum age limit to which the Initiative can apply is raised to 29 or 30 years, and the European Parliament must also commit itself to this. Even more important, however, is that the Union resumes a path of economic growth without which this instrument, like others, will be able to achieve very little results. Resumption of public and private investments, creation of tangible and intangible infrastructures, overcoming the rigidities of public budgets: these must be the work priorities of the European Commission which will be set up for the next five years.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution.The EU must redouble its efforts to tackle youth unemployment, which now stands at 5 million under 25.That is why we are calling for the youth guarantee to be extended to people under the age of 30.I also support our desire to increase the budget for this guarantee and will demand that it be increased to 21 billion euros as soon as possible.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: written. - I supported the Resolution of my colleague Case on youth unemployment. The EU faces a high youth unemployment rate of 22.5%, while in Croatia youth unemployment under the age of 25 is as high as 48.7%. The issue of youth unemployment is important in the context of achieving the goals of the Europe 2020 strategy, which plans to increase employment between the ages of 20 and 64 to 75% and reduce early school leaving to 10%. It is a great responsibility of the members to focus on devising concrete measures for youth employment in order to help young people not to be socially excluded - without work, education or training. Youth unemployment in Croatia has grown into a social and economic problem, and the Government has offered one-off and insufficient measures of a social nature that will not affect higher employment in the long run. I believe that it is necessary to harmonize the education system with the requirements of the modern labor market. Young people need to be encouraged and involved in decision-making in order to venture into self-employment and entrepreneurial ventures and to support small and medium-sized enterprises that have great potential in initiating economic recovery and youth employment. I expect the Government to effectively use the € 125 million available for youth employment under the end of 2015 under the Youth Guarantee instrument.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted for the resolution on youth employment in order to push forward the European Parliament's proposals to the Member States.The European Parliament regularly suggests investing in youth employment, but states do not always follow the recommendations.Youth unemployment is a scourge, however, especially in the countries of southern Europe with Greece, where one in two young people is unemployed.I supported the proposal to include in this category of unemployed young people, who range from 16 to 25 years old, also the 25-30 age group, sometimes qualified and graduated and yet unemployed.This category of young people should also benefit from investments and aid.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: written. - The fight against youth unemployment must be an absolute priority for the new Commission. The resolution, which was adopted today by the European Parliament by a large majority, has a strong social-democratic signature. Important demands from us are, for example, that measures against youth unemployment are included in the European Semester on a mandatory basis for the Member States. We Social Democrats have long been calling for a rights-based approach to be pursued, i.e. a legal entitlement for young people to measures such as the youth guarantee. There is also an urgent need to increase the budget for the European Youth Guarantee. Instead of the previously promised 8 billion euros, according to the ILO, at least 21 billion euros are needed in the euro zone alone to effectively implement the youth guarantee. I voted for the resolution because it is important to send a strong signal to the new Commission too. Because the price we pay for youth unemployment is enormous - not just financially.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: in writing. - The unequaled youth unemployment rate in Europe: more than 5.3 million, is a human, family and social tragedy. It is the risk of intergenerational solidarity that is broken but also of a possible exodus of a whole generation towards more dynamic regions! The Youth Guarantee, to support the employment of young people under 25, is a response to this scourge. And the 6 billion allocated to it remains a modest sum given the fragility of the labor market and the low employability of young graduates or not. This is why we must activate all the tools available to stem this scourge and make the reduction of youth unemployment the social priority of this legislature. Certain avenues are listed in the resolution voted on this afternoon: - better use of ESF funds for projects linked to youth employment; - make the activation of employment support measures binding in the specific recommendations per country; - strengthen the links between vocational education and the business world in order to maintain a solid industrial fabric in Europe and aim for the 20% of GDP target for 2020, as the new President of the Commission has committed to doing.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing.- (PT) I voted in favor of this resolution, which points out ways and some solutions for combating unemployment among the younger sections of the population.The holistic view embodied in this resolution is a good symbol of how to combat this drama: globally, whether using different policy instruments or using different levels of power - from local to European, through national and regional;involving the private sphere of the economy and the training and educational agents in solving the problem;using a multisectoral view, not forgetting / putting aside the more traditional sectors of the economy that should complement new technologies.The strong support of this House for this resolution reinforces the need for the measures provided for in it to be implemented as soon as possible by our Member States and the European Commission.In the name of our youth, for the sake of the future.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I have not been able to vote in favor of this resolution because, despite containing some points that I consider interesting to solve the very serious situation that the youth of the European Union are going through, it does not consider austerity policies as the main cause of this situation of the European Union and the Troika, nor the responsibility of the Member States. Many Governments of the Southern European States are trying to expel their young people as a way to reduce the social unrest they go through due to the imposition of the policies of austerity. However, the resolution contains positive points when it appeals to the need to reduce inequalities, the relaxation of the rules of the European Social Fund so that projects are carried out, recognizes the scarcity of resources allocated to the Youth Employment Initiative, etc. However, this resolution is insufficient for the main problem facing the European economy and that is why I have not been able to vote in its favor. These funds represent a band-aid on a gunshot wound.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: in writing. - Employment is not only one of the abstract indicators, it is a telling picture of the condition of society and the economy. In principle, the wrong approach is to try to counteract the problems in the labor market itself and to leave the issue of their causes as secondary. The basis is the state of the economy. For the economy to develop in a proper, healthy way, it is also necessary to provide education tailored to its needs at all levels of education. An important help in finding a job is not only education, but also practical skills. The development of a system of internships and apprenticeships is real help. Their costs could be co-financed for companies from national or EU funds. The most important thing is the attitude of the unemployed themselves. In many cases, it was not the lack of qualifications and skills that determined their situation, but the lack of willingness to take advantage of the opportunities they face. We live in times when creating a sense of entrepreneurship is almost as important as the knowledge and skills in a given field. Therefore, creating entrepreneurial attitudes should be high on the list of priorities aimed at combating unemployment, especially youth unemployment. The social assistance system should also be rationalized so as not to provide care to the so-called crooks and lazybones. Summing up, there is a need for greater activity of the government, local governments and other institutions dealing with this problem.

name: Sion Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. - The EPLP did not support Amendment 8 to paragraph 45, because it is tautologous and misleading. In seeking to stress that labour mobility ‘must be qualified’, the amendment disingenuously implies that labour mobility in the EU is currently not qualified. This is false. Citizens are free to move within the Union to work, but do not have an unqualified right to move and live anywhere within the Union. That is a myth, disingenuously promoted by this amendment.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. - The number of jobs and the quality of them are deteriorating in Europe. The statistics on youth employment in Europe are downright maddening. In order to make the Youth Employment Initiative a reality, many Member States are actively implementing measures funded by the YEI (six billion euros) and the European Social Fund (over ten billion euros each year). YEI funding has a key role to play as it must directly support young people by providing them with a first professional experience, internship, apprenticeship or training. The funds from the YEI and the European Social Fund planned for the period 2014-2020 must be used in regions where youth unemployment was above 25% in 2012 for actions in favor of young people under 25 and mainly in favor of young people who do not work, do not attend studies or training. Twenty Member States have such regions and can benefit from these funds. Europe must promote the direct creation of jobs, internships or continuing training. We must do our utmost to ensure that the tools for recovery and the creation of European jobs are put in place.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. - Youth unemployment is one of the biggest challenges of our time. In Catalonia, where I come from, youth unemployment already affects more than 50% of the young population, and many young people have to leave the country in order to get a job. I hope that this resolution sends a clear signal to the Commission and the Council in order to push with stronger regulations and projects to help to solve this issue. The problem of youth unemployment will not be solved at European level, but the EU can help to improve Member States’ practices in tackling this issue.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: written.- Although the Resolution contains interesting elements, it falls short of the urgency and scope of the problem.Furthermore, important amendments denouncing the consequences of austerity policies have been rejected.For this reason, I have decided to abstain from voting.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I have not been able to vote in favor of this resolution because, despite containing some points that I consider of extreme interest to solve the very serious situation that the youth of the European Union are going through, it does not hold the Member States responsible for this situation. Many governments in southern European states are trying to expel their youth as a way to reduce the social unrest they are experiencing due to the imposition of austerity policies. However, the resolution contains positive points when it appeals to the need to reduce inequalities, the relaxation of the rules of the European Social Fund so that projects are carried out, recognizes the scarcity of resources allocated to the Youth Employment Initiative, etc. However, this resolution is insufficient for the main problem facing the European economy and that is why I have not been able to vote in its favor. These funds represent a band-aid on a gunshot wound.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - In this resolution on youth employment, we have found no critical analysis in relation to the other aid packages applied in the past. No serious analysis is done on the causes of this scourge. Several factors are pointed out in isolation, but without any consequence in terms of the proposals or lines mentioned. In this sense, we continue to privilege outdated solutions that have not contributed in the past nor will contribute in the future to solve this problem. In other words, on the mother of all the reasons that lead to the frightening numbers of youth unemployment, that is, the austerity policies combined with a systematic destruction of the entire heritage of rights built laboriously over decades through the struggle of generations of workers . Nothing is proposed and nothing is said about the continuity of these same policies, a course publicly taken by the EU institutions. On the other hand, none of the GUE / NGL proposals, which pointed to more consistent solutions, were approved. In this sense, my vote can only be that of the rejection of this report.

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ (PPE)
text: in writing. - I support with my vote the resolution on youth employment. Youth unemployment rates in the EU are unprecedented. The EU and the Member States must work together on a comprehensive approach to combating youth unemployment. The statistics of recent years are more than disappointing. The numbers speak for themselves, as 25% of young people of working age, ie 5.5 million young people, are unemployed in Europe, while in my country, Greece, this percentage reaches 60%. In Greece, young people are migrating in search of work and livelihood - a phenomenon that is observed in the countries of the South that are in economic crisis. We can not afford to hinder. We need responsible and targeted policies that will bring tangible results: -accelerating the implementation of the Youth Employment Initiative, so that eligible Member States receive funding as soon as possible, -creating sustainable and high-quality jobs, and -developing a plan action for youth employment and the possibility of choices in the labor market and ensuring a decent income. In an ever-aging Europe, our young people are the FUTURE of Europe. So let's get them out of the sidelines!

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D)
text: written. - We have been dealing with the horrendously high youth unemployment for some time now. It has been over two years since I stood here in plenary and warned of rising youth unemployment. Then, as now, there was justified criticism that too little attention was paid to this problem and the demand that the search for solutions to youth unemployment should move into the political center. Even today, many steps are still necessary to get this problem under control - rapid action is urgently required. Fortunately, there are fewer who have underestimated the problem. The present joint resolution is therefore very welcome. It not only calls for more means to combat youth unemployment, it also calls for a legal framework that defines binding European minimum standards for implementing the youth guarantee. She calls for a legal entitlement approach when it comes to implementing the Youth Guarantee. Compared to the political majority belief two years ago, this is a great step forward.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: signed up. - I voted in favor of the resolution on employment among young people because they, especially those under 25, are the hardest hit by the effects of the crisis, but they are also the most confident in the European ideal. Gathered in May in Strasbourg, more than 5,000 young people gathered their proposals in a document entitled "Ideas for a Better Europe". I am glad that I managed to encourage and support 50 young Hungarians from Transylvania to participate in EYE 2014 and in the elaboration of this document. They are sounding the alarm that they are "a stuck generation" not only because of the crisis, but also because of the huge gap between educational supply and labor market demand. I believe that the top priority for the next five years is to find ways to help the millions of unemployed young people find a job, but also to support the education systems in the Member States to connect with reality. Convinced that only by working for young people do you really work for the future of your community, I collaborate with the Hungarian youth organization in Transylvania - MIÉRT and with YEPP - the EPP youth organization, and I support their initiatives.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing.- The data regarding youth unemployment are increasingly alarming: in Europe it has reached 23%, in Italy even 43% making the situation serious both from an economic point of view, but also from a social one, placing people in a situationof inferiority and leading them to consider themselves unsuitable.The lack of work in Europe must be a matter of primary importance for governments;great political choices and the mobilization of all cultural, social and entrepreneurial forces are needed.Europe must encourage Member States to share best practices that have proven to be effective, to coordinate their strategies and to find common solutions to the problem of youth unemployment.I voted in favor of this motion for a resolution because if we want to build a young and united Europe, it is precisely on young workers that we must focus, giving them a guarantee of the future.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: in writing. - The KKE votes against the joint resolution and at the same time rejects all the draft resolutions submitted to the Plenary for the employment of young people because, despite their individual differences, they identify with their strategy, accept the anti-popular strategy of the EU "Europe 2020", project as The cause of the situation is one or the other management mix of the capitalist path of development, each acknowledging in turn its support for it. They support the subsidy of employers, in addition to hot money, with tax exemptions and contribution exemptions, with free labor, subsidizing their profitability in the name of competitiveness. Their aim is to drastically reduce the price of labor, as a means of overcoming the crisis for the benefit of capital and at the expense of the working class and young people. In other words, any capitalist recovery will be based on the demolition of all the conquests of the workers. This policy not only did not tackle youth unemployment, but worsened their position, reduced the general level of wages, generalized flexible forms of employment and further sharpened the exploitation of workers and youth.

name: Janusz Władysław Zemke (S&D)
text: in writing. - The resolution does not adequately address the fundamental social problem in Europe, which is the lack of jobs for young people. It is worth recalling that this is a group of 26 million people in Europe, including, unfortunately, hundreds of thousands of young people in Poland. Resolutions are vague, they are full of the words "must" and "should", without emphasizing the specifics. These facts should primarily be about supporting small and medium-sized enterprises, which create 75 percent of all jobs in Europe. These enterprises should receive measurable financial support when employing people up to 30 years of age. In particular, states should shoulder the cost of welfare benefits for people who start working for the first time. The second area must be a € 300 billion program of infrastructure investments in Europe, including the transmission grid and broadband internet. Investments create not only new services, but are also the basis for creating new jobs. Thirdly, within the framework of the EU funds, a special pool should be distinguished to support vocational and technical education at all levels of education and funds for paid internships for pupils, students and graduates of schools who would like to develop in production and service enterprises. If we do not leave the sphere of generally correct statements and get down to business, unemployment among young people will continue.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - 23% of young people in the EU are unemployed, and in some countries, such as Greece and Spain, more than half of young people are unemployed. In countries like Portugal, attempts are being made to manipulate the statistics, omitting that the slight decrease in this statistic is due to the untied bleeding of emigration, the growing number of young people who are forced to leave the country, a situation with only equivalent if we return to times of poverty of the fascist dictatorship. And omitting that the jobs created have precarious employment links, substituting work with rights for work without rights. Any resolution that, in fact, had the real intention of changing the state of the situation, would have to demand a break with the main EU economic policies responsible for creating unemployment. In the joint resolution supported by this majority in Parliament, neither Troika programs nor Economic Governance are mentioned as causing the massive destruction of jobs and the weakening of social and labor rights. Omitting the central issue in such a matter of concern is tantamount to masking the problem, laundering the right-wing policies and political forces that, both in Portugal and in the EU, have always supported them - the right and social democracy.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing.- The resolution on youth employment.The number of young people out of work in Europe is alarming and growing.The most vulnerable group among them are young people with disabilities and from socially disadvantaged backgrounds.We therefore appreciate that a point has been included in our resolution in the resolution, which calls on the Member States to pay special attention to young unemployed people at risk and to create tools and support services for better integration of people with disabilities into the labor market.At the same time, however, we are convinced that more than spending millions of euros on temporary subsidized jobs, which we are not tackling the problem but only postponing, we need to better set up youth education and improve the business environment.

name: Udo Voigt (NI). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, if you are still here!As a newly elected member, I am a little disconcerted that there are no longer ten people in the hall at a meeting that was scheduled until 2 p.m.I voted in favor of the resolution on Iraq, but I think that we are getting nowhere with resolutions.The whole region has been destabilized, and I ask myself: what has this war between the Americans and their allies brought there if people are being persecuted there again today, if Christians are being persecuted there, if people are being tortured and ill-treated?An entire region has been destabilized and, given the situation, more needs to be done there.The largest oil reserves are in this region, and we do not know today whether the Sharia will rule there tomorrow or whether the values of the Christian West will continue to be represented.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: May I say by way of explanation that the explanations of vote are there for individual Members after the vote so that they can explain why they voted.This part of the plenary session does not have the function of every colleague listening.It is common knowledge.I explain this because the audience up there reacted.I would also like to say explicitly that it is neither in the Parliament in the country I come from nor in this Parliament that there are demonstrations of approval or disapproval from the visitors' stands.Mr Voigt, there is no debate on this.

name: John Stuart Agnew (EFDD)
text: in writing. - We feel that whilst certain British politicians may have a case to answer in court for the war in Iraq, we are concerned that the wording of this resolution could lead to brave British service men and women being prosecuted as well. Our party could never agree to anything that could open the door for attacks and prosecutions of our service men and women.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. - We feel that whilst certain British politicians may have a case to answer in court for the war in Iraq, we are concerned that the wording of this resolution could lead to brave British service men and women being prosecuted as well. Our party could never agree to anything that could open the door for attacks and prosecutions of our service men and women.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have not been able to vote in favor of this resolution because it waives any responsibility to the United States and the other occupying armies that unleashed this increase in violence since the invasion of the country.Despite the use of false evidence and lies to justify itself, it seems that this Parliament does not intend to hold the protagonists of an invasion that has disintegrated the country, leading to the development of terrorist movements, to account.The resolution also does not criticize the responsibility of the current Government of Iraq in developing the present situation of violence due to its sectarian policies.I have not been able to vote in favor of this resolution because not all those responsible for the tragic situation that the country is going through are accused.

name: Andrus Ansip (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I support the resolution because the deteriorating security situation in Iraq is extremely worrying.I condemn the violent attacks by extremist groups in the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant and by other Sunni extremist groups.Of particular condemnation are the human rights violations committed during the attacks, such as the execution of imprisoned soldiers and the violence against civilians and objects.The deepening humanitarian crisis due to the large-scale wave of refugees resulting from the conflict is also worrying.The Iraqi Government must make efforts to protect civilians, ensure the security of internally displaced persons and ensure that humanitarian aid reaches all those in need.Iraq is a key partner for the European Union in the Middle East.I consider it important for the European Union to continue to contribute to the stabilization and democratization process in Iraq, on the basis of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement concluded in May 2012.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing.- While I agree with the positions supported in this resolution which analyzes the situation in Iraq, I believe that no noteworthy intervention by the EU is proposed, other than a sharp increase in expenditure on so-called "humanitarian aid" which I believe in any casenot very effective and incisive, for these reasons I expressed myself with a vote of abstention.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution on the situation in Iraq.I welcome the European Parliament's support for the Iraqi authorities in the fight against terrorism or the invitation to put an end to all activities aimed at disseminating extremist Islamist ideologies.The deterioration of security conditions in Iraq cannot continue.Respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms is necessary.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of the resolution to strongly condemn the attacks by the Islamic State (IS) against the Iraqi state and its citizens, and in particular extrajudicial executions and the imposition of a strict interpretation of the Sharia. At the same time, I urge the Iraqi security forces to respect their international commitments on human rights and fundamental freedoms in the fight against IS and other terrorist groups. I think that the answer to the question of security must be combined with a sustainable political solution that involves all components of Iraqi society and takes into account their legitimate demands. I believe that, after the April elections, a government with an inclusive agenda, representing the political, religious and ethnic diversity of Iraqi society, must urgently be formed to end the bloodshed and fragmentation of the country. Furthermore, the military should be reorganized in an inclusive, non-sectarian and impartial way. Finally, I think that the EU must develop a comprehensive strategic approach for the Middle East and that Iran, Saudi Arabia and the other Gulf states must participate in the efforts to ease tensions in Iraq.

name: James Carver and Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. - We feel that whilst certain British politicians may have a case to answer in court for the war in Iraq, we are concerned that the wording of this resolution could lead to brave British service men and women from being prosecuted as well. Our party could never agree to anything that could open the door for attacks on and prosecutions of our service men and women.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing.- Regarding the serious regional crisis involving the territories of Iraq and Syria, the 5 Star MoVement takes sides against extremism, against religious fundamentalism and the continuous struggle between Sunnis and Shiites that obscures and mystifies the reasons of so many suffering families.The instability of the region, which has been going on for some time now, has created a humanitarian emergency of immense proportions with hundreds of thousands of people fleeing their destroyed or looted homes.The interventions by the armed forces of the West have worsened local situations already tense and complicated from many points of view and have never been decisive in any case.Let us stop external interference and let the peoples to self-determine.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing.- Unfortunately it seems clear to me that we have done something wrong in Iraq.I refer to all the international forces that intervened together with the United States in 2003. Looking at today's very worrying situation, we must recognize the mistakes made, whether it is how the campaign was managed, the relationship between objectives and results, orof other strategic or procedural issues.Now that the damage is done, it must be remedied and the EU cannot let it go back to the Middle Ages.It is therefore appropriate to develop an overall strategy that is able to lead the country towards a more stable situation, safer for citizens, and more in keeping with the aspirations of citizens.The tone and content of the resolution seemed to me in line with my thinking, and that is why I voted in favor.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have not been able to vote in favor of this resolution because it waives any responsibility to the United States and the other occupying armies that unleashed this increase in violence since the invasion of the country.Despite the use of false evidence and lies to justify itself, it seems that this Parliament does not intend to hold the protagonists of an invasion accountable that has disintegrated the country, giving rise to the development of terrorist movements.The resolution also does not criticize the responsibility of the current Government of Iraq in developing the present situation of violence due to its sectarian policies.I have not been able to vote in favor of this resolution because not all those responsible for the tragic situation that the country is going through are accused.

name: Corina Creţu (S&D)
text: signed up. - The adoption of the resolution on the situation in Iraq follows on from the European Parliament's previous positions on this issue and demonstrates that the European Union is making concrete efforts to resolve tensions in the region. By signing the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with Iraq in 2012, the European Union has pledged to support the country's transition to democracy, but the rapid deterioration of the political, social and economic situation makes it a goal to at least achieve this goal. in the short term, extremely difficult. The fragmented political scene is still unable to put an end to the continuing waves of violence fueled by the terrorist group "Islamic State", responsible for kidnappings, rapes, forced marriages and summary executions. That is why it is necessary to form, as a matter of urgency, a broadly representative Government, emanating from the results of the parliamentary elections held at the end of April this year. The European Union's financial supplementation of humanitarian assistance to Iraq is welcome, but the situation can only be eased if the Iraqi authorities join these efforts to a greater extent. The creation of the necessary framework for dialogue in the region will be possible only after the terrorist danger has been removed.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This resolution conceals a set of facts with the aim of bleaching the responsibilities of the USA and Great Britain in the situation in Iraq (and, by the way, also of the current president of the European Commission - the sad butler of Lajes), seeking to ensure the continuation of their impunity. Firstly, the aggression and occupation of Iraq, invoking the existence of weapons of mass destruction - a confirmed lie, all the more hypocritical when the invaders themselves used weapons of the same type against the Iraqis (case of Fallujah), victimizing many thousands of people. innocent and leaving a heavy legacy for many generations. Second, the dismantling of Iraq that the occupying forces initiated, with the promotion of widespread violence, religious integration and sectarianism, the intensification of ethnic divisions as a diversion in the face of the brutal degradation of living conditions in the country that owns the farm. world's largest oil reserve. Thirdly, the forces that occupy several cities in northern Iraq are moving from Syria where they served the interests of the United States and the EU powers in destabilizing the country, moving now to other places but serving the same objective: to redraw the map of the Middle East depending on the strategic interests of imperialism.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing.- In the EP plenary debate, it has been said several times that the current situation in Iraq has in some way been caused by the Member States that took part in the military invasion of Iraq without a UN mandate.We removed Hussein to make way for the caliphate years later.It is also proof of the misconception of the implementation of Western democracy in the countries of the Middle East.However, the truth is that religious and ethnic cleansing is taking place in Iraq and the EU is just watching and adopting an unresolved resolution.At the same time, Iraq has a nuclear program that can be a threat and against which we are completely powerless at the moment, because we have failed at a time when we were able to deal with the situation actively and responsibly.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: in writing.- Deeply concerned about the violent insurgency affecting Iraq, I voted in favor of a resolution on recent developments in the country.Indeed, fighting between Iraqi government forces and Sunni rebels led by ISIS (formerly ISIS in Iraq and the Levant) has resulted in the deaths of thousands of people and the displacement of thousands of refugees.I strongly condemn the attacks perpetrated by the Islamic State terrorist group and other armed groups that commit acts of violence against the civilian population.I call on the Iraqi government and all political leaders to take the necessary measures to ensure the safety and protection of residents, especially vulnerable minorities such as Christians.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution on Iraq which condemns the violence committed by Islamist movements and supports the government's fight against these movements, while stressing the need for a viable political solution for the stabilization of the country andthe return to the security of its citizens.I welcome the adoption of this text by a very large majority.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. - As a co-signatory of the PPE Group resolution, I welcome the fact that my amendments on the fate of Christians have been incorporated into the joint resolution. It was essential to recall the guidelines on the promotion and protection of freedom of religion or belief adopted on June 24, 2013, so that the EU exerts its full weight to protect Christians in Iraq, many of whom are 'collapses. We remember the barbaric attack of October 31, 2005 in the Syro-Catholic Cathedral of Our Lady of Perpetual Help in Baghdad, claimed by the Iraqi branch of al-Qaeda. Multiple bloody episodes have since unfolded, and Christians now face the abuses of Islamic State jihadists and choose exodus. The EU must advocate a comprehensive approach to the region, involving Iran, Saudi Arabia and other Gulf countries in efforts to defuse the conflict in Iraq. In addition, light must be shed on the private funding that would benefit jihadist groups active in Iraq, without directly calling into question the governments of the Gulf States as suggested by recital D of the joint resolution.

name: Kaja Kallas (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I support the resolution because I support the unity, sovereignty and territorial integrity of Iraq, which are necessary for the stability and economic development of the country itself and of the region as a whole.I call on the Iraqi Central Government and the Iraqi Autonomous Government of Kurdistan to work closely together for the stability of the country.The security crisis in Iraq can only be resolved through genuine dialogue between Shiites, Sunnis and Kurds.

name: Paloma López (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have not been able to vote in favor of this resolution because it waives any responsibility to the United States and the other occupying armies that unleashed this increase in violence since the invasion of the country.Despite the use of false evidence and lies to justify it, it seems that this Parliament does not intend to hold the protagonists of an invasion that has disintegrated the country, giving rise to the development of terrorist movements, to account.The resolution also does not criticize the responsibility of the current Government of Iraq in developing the present situation of violence due to its sectarian policies.I have not been able to vote in favor of this resolution because not all those responsible for the tragic situation that the country is going through are accused.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution. The deterioration of the situation in Iraq is very worrying. EU governments and others must continue to provide the Iraqi Government with the appropriate support and we cannot let the country slide into domestic conflict.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This draft resolution on the situation in Iraq is typical of the aboveground and timeless proposals produced by the European Union in foreign policy. If the text provides a relatively accurate diagnosis of the disastrous situation in this country, it eludes the causes. "The Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant", created in 2003, is first and foremost the product of the wars waged against Iraq by the United States and its allies. This resolution follows on from the empire's subcontractor policy pursued by the EU from 2005 to 2013 through its delegation in Baghdad. Its central mission was to "strengthen the rule of law and promote a culture of respect for human rights in Iraq by carrying out training activities for Iraqi officials from the police forces, the judiciary or the administration. penitentiary ”. Mission accomplished ? The Iraqi people deserve more than these hypocritical statements. I therefore vote against this resolution.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing.- I strongly condemn the attacks directed against civilian targets, such as schools, hospitals and places of worship, the use of executions, expressing my deep concern at the deteriorating security conditions experienced in Iraq, as well as the humanitarian crisis experienced.For this reason, I voted in favor of the resolution tabled by the European Parliament.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution as it seeks to safeguard the livelihood of the Iraqi people and endeavours to protect those vulnerable from the continuing acts of violence perpetrated against them. Moreover, the resolution aims to further strengthen the EU’s efforts to assist Iraq in promoting democracy, human rights, good governance and the rule of law.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing. - The situation in Iraq today is extremely serious. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees reports a million Iraqi citizens displaced by recent clashes between the extremist terrorist group Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (ISIL), the regular army and d 'other groups. Not only is the collapse of the Iraqi state a threat to the unity of the country, it also directly concerns Europe and the world beyond. I condemn in the strongest terms the acts of terrorist groups and the financial support aimed at strengthening negative forces such as ISIL which today threaten the country of partition, with the possible creation of a jihadistan in the west of Syria and eastern Iraq. It is urgent to recreate the conditions for a political dialogue including all parties, all the forces of the nation and bringing together all communities in order to face together this new threat. Only an inclusive political solution, approved by all components of the Iraqi population, will lead to an end to the crisis.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. - I support this resolution on the situation in Iraq, which calls on the Iraqi government to make every effort to protect all civilians and provide essential services and safety to all of its population who are affected by the surge of the IS and welcomes the increase in the EU humanitarian assistance to Iraq.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing.- Through this resolution, I voted to denounce the deterioration in security conditions in Iraq.The advance of the Islamic State (a dissident al-Qaeda faction) in Iraq has been accompanied by summary executions, the imposition of Sharia law and the destruction of places of worship and historic sites.The European Union had to denounce and condemn these actions as quickly as possible.I am outraged at the persecution suffered by the Christian community in this region and at the displacement of 10,000 of them in Qaraqosh.Finally, the text underlines and denounces the participation of citizens of the European Union in acts of terrorism in this zone and our wish to bring these people to justice.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: written. - I do not share some aspects of the motion for a resolution on the immediate causes of the problems in Iraq. Sometimes none are mentioned or everything is presented in a very abstract way - as if ISIS suddenly came down on us from nowhere. There have been around 500,000 deaths in Iraq since 2003 - more than the United Kingdom or Italy suffered in deaths in World War II. The US wreaked havoc in the region. The Assad opposition was supported at all costs and despite all warnings - unofficially also through weapons and training. Now the weapons are in the hands of an "ISIS". You really have to ask yourself now: Is this all on purpose? Again it seems as if the arsonist is calling the fire brigade himself for me and offers himself to do so again. In this way, multiple earnings can be made with the war: arms sales to everyone and manipulation of oil prices through induced crises. In return, however, I share the demands of the motion for a resolution that the political and humanitarian grievances caused by the ISIS expansion should now be countered more decisively - the child has just fallen into the well. Considering the motion for a resolution as a whole, I have therefore abstained from voting.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: in writing. - The unacceptable resolution of the monopoly coalition - EPP, Social Democrats, Liberals - along with the Conservatives - Reformists and the Greens on Iraq, provocatively portrays as ostensibly defenders of the rights of the Iraqi people, as mediators For years now, forces such as the United States, which continues to maintain an occupying police-military force in Iraq, and the EU, which has supported imperialist intervention in the country from the outset, with its member states actively participating in the occupation forces, other regional powers that also take part in intra-imperialist rivalries over control of wealth-producing resources and energy routes. The resolution blames the al-Maliki government as a factor in confronting the Islamists when it has enormous responsibilities because it strengthens the Islamist line by backing the US occupation and its anti-popular policies.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution to underline the urgency of the situation in Iraq and the potential destabilization of the Iraq-Syria region.A real territory controlled by extremists of the Islamic State must absolutely be prevented.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted for the motion for a resolution on the situation in Iraq, which denounces the terrorist attacks by the Islamist group EEIL, which currently occupies a large part of Iraq.This country failed to defend itself at first against a terrorist group supported by part of the Iraqi population, both for religious reasons, and both for regionalist and tribal reasons.This situation has led the United States and Europe to mobilize to help stop the advance of terrorists.The creation of an Islamist caliphate in Iraq is the symbol of the tendencies of domination of these terrorist groups.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I am very concerned about the humanitarian crisis and the massive displacement of civilians in Iraq. Yesterday, the European Parliament condemned the attacks of the Islamic State in Iraq against Iraqi citizens and the Iraqi State and those directed against civilian targets. And I am delighted: in this resolution that I supported, Parliament called on all political leaders, in particular Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki, "to ensure that a unity government will be formed of urgently ”. While we support the authorities in the fight against terrorism and armed / terrorist groups, we have also called for security interventions to be accompanied by a lasting political solution that involves all components of Iraqi society and responds to their discontent. legitimate. Because we must take all the necessary measures to ensure the safety and protection of all Iraqi citizens! We also called on regional actors to contribute to efforts aimed at promoting security and stability in Iraq and called on the international community to facilitate a regional dialogue on Middle East issues. The EU must develop a comprehensive approach to the region.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have not been able to vote in favor of this resolution because it waives any responsibility to the United States and the other occupying armies that unleashed this increase in violence since the invasion of the country.Despite the use of false evidence and lies to justify itself, it seems that this Parliament does not intend to hold the protagonists of an invasion accountable that has disintegrated the country, giving rise to the development of terrorist movements.The resolution also does not criticize the responsibility of the current Government of Iraq in developing the present situation of violence due to its sectarian policies.I have not been able to vote in favor of this resolution because not all those responsible for the tragic situation that the country is going through are accused.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. - Iraq now has a Shiite regime linked to Iran and supported by Iran which today is Saudi Arabia's main competitor in terms of regional hegemony. This Saudi Arabia / Iran confrontation rubs off on the Saudis' relationship with Shiite Iraq. In my opinion, the Saudis have no interest in Iraq regaining its power and neither do the Iranians. The idea that Iraq must not rise from its ashes is shared by both countries. In fact, there is a proxy war being waged by the two states in Iraq and Syria. By favoring the radical Sunni fringe, the Saudis will ultimately pay the price for this policy. The Saudis drafted into the groups could come back to the country and that is the real problem. There would be internal destabilization if these fighters returned to Saudi Arabia, and then the implosion of Iraq. I think Saudi Arabia has had a short-sighted policy in believing that the implosion of Iraq and Syria would have no consequences on its own territory and its society. It's wrong. The delicate balance that the Saudis have managed to maintain internally is actually unstable, for all of these reasons.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing.- I supported the joint resolution, although I do not think that this Parliament can influence anything else about what is happening in Iraq today.We are witnessing the collapse of a state whose elites have been too selfish for too long.At the same time, we are witnessing the demise of a thousand-year-old Christian community that was forced to leave the land of its ancestors, and today its members are refugees fighting for survival.And we are witnessing radical Islamic fundamentalists, funded by plundered Iraqi money, establishing a state that embodies sectarian violence and hatred of everything that makes us human.If we really want to help someone in this situation, instead of a political resolution, we should urgently look for a way to effectively protect Iraqi Christians.
