Third, the forces that occupy several cities in northern Iraq are moving from Syria where they served the interests of the United States and the EU powers in destabilizing the country, now heading elsewhere but with the same objective: to serve the purposes of draw the map of the Greater Middle East that the United States wants to impose on the peoples of the region.

name: Udo Voigt (NI). -
text: Mister President!I voted in favor of this motion.But the proposal does not go far enough for me.In yesterday's debate, Mr Lambsdorff in particular spoke of Israel's right to self-defense.I think that one must add here that a country like Palestine, which has been occupied for four decades, which has been divided, around which a wall is being built, this country where hundreds of thousands and tens of thousands are in refugee camps in neighboring countries, is of course also a righton self defense.But I hope that peace will soon return to the region and that we will contribute to it with our resolutions and perhaps also with active political action, but always take both sides into account and not just one.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted against this resolution because I do not share the equidistance with which the parties are treated when Israel is massacring the civilian population.With more than 600 Palestinians killed in the Gaza Strip as a result of the Israeli attacks in its latest offensive, it is proven that Israel is committing crimes of genocide, war, aggression and crimes against humanity, crimes typified by the law, intentional and persecuted.by the International Criminal Court.Faced with this situation of the military assassinating the civilian population, the equidistance is obscene.The freezing of the Association Agreement with the State of Israel or any type of sanction against it is not requested, losing the opportunity to demand compliance with international law.I have therefore decided to vote against this resolution.

name: Andrus Ansip (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I support the resolution because I unequivocally condemn the bombing of Israel and the abduction of Jewish adolescents in June.The tense situation between Israel and Palestine is very worrying.We call on the parties to take all measures to prevent the situation from escalating further.The European Union must contribute to initiatives that lead to a truce.I welcome the Egyptian Government's proposal for a ceasefire and hope that it will be implemented.What is happening again shows that without a lasting solution, violence can break out again at any moment.As a precondition for lasting peace, I consider the recognition of the right of Israel by the Palestinian political forces to exist as a state.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing.- Although it is a fairly balanced resolution that calls for a stronger role for the EU in the current Israeli-Palestinian crisis, I find that there are some controversial points in it, which is why I voted in abstention.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: in writing.- I spoke in favor of adopting the resolution on the escalation of violence between Israel and Palestine.The situation is worrying and causes tragic human losses.This resolution calls for an end to rocket fire and urges the international community, and in particular the United Nations Security Council, to find an appropriate response to the current crisis without delay.Peace talks must be initiated to fulfill the right to live in peace and security of Israeli and Palestinian citizens.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing.- Today I voted in favor of the resolution calling for an immediate end to rocket attacks on Israel and Israeli military action against Gaza.I also call for the EU foreign policy officer and member states to do more to support an immediate ceasefire, to stop all acts of violence that threaten civilians and to persuade Israelis and Palestinians to resume direct peace talks.As regards the resumption of direct peace talks, I think it is essential to encourage the main regional political players, in particular Egypt and Jordan, to continue their efforts to calm the situation.Non-violent means are the only way to achieve a just and lasting peace between Israelis and Palestinians.These negotiations must achieve concrete results and the EU must play a more active role.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing.- A humanitarian tragedy involving almost 2 million people has been taking place in Palestine for some time, we do not want to minimize the damage suffered by Israeli citizens, but we want to emphasize the proportion of the conflict.The Gaza Strip is, in fact, surrounded by a constant embargo that prevents the emergency services from functioning well: lack of food, water and medicines make the situation intolerable for the resident population.What we see before us is a succession of appeals to keep the peace, to avoid further bloodshed.They are appeals that go unheard, again and again.To suffer the consequences are children, women and the sick who cannot receive treatment perhaps because they are on the wrong side of the border.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. - Prolonging military conflict in Gaza will only spiral into further violence and the EU must fully assert its influence to bring it to an end. I condemn the rocket attacks into Israeli territory but also the disproportionate use of military force by the Israeli authorities. The spirals of violence and retaliation that periodically emerge in the region lead only to the loss of innocent lives. The best, long-term path to peace and security for both sides is a comprehensive agreement for a two-state solution that allows for a viable Palestinian state. Israelʼs continued settlement expansion in the occupied territories only serves to undermine all the fragile work done to reach that outcome. Through its close trade and cooperation ties with Israel, the EU can and must exert more pressure on Israel towards a sustainable, long-term solution.  The alternative is to keep paying for essential infrastructure and humanitarian aid in the wake of every outburst of violence, while the Israeli-Palestinian conflict continues to fester and claim innocent lives against an increasingly dangerous and unpredictable Middle-Eastern backdrop.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. - In addition to Iraq, the border between Israel and Palestine also presents a very serious situation and on which action is needed. Going back to the historical roots of this conflict is useful only for academic purposes, in my opinion, because it would involve an evaluation of which reasons are more or less important and valid, an evaluation as absurd as it is useless. An overall strategy should also be drawn here: something that allows the Israeli people to lower their guard and direct their scientific research towards sectors other than the war industry, and that allows the Palestinian people to increase their well-being and learn to live together. peacefully with their Jewish neighbors as well as with their Muslim ones. The EU itself could be an example, since it was born to end an old rivalry. It is our moral responsibility to allow the children of Israelis and Palestinians to grow up in a peaceful land, luck which we have had and which I sincerely wish everyone.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted against this resolution because I do not share the equidistance with which the parties are treated when Israel is massacring the civilian population.With more than 600 Palestinians killed in the Gaza Strip as a result of the Israeli attacks in its latest offensive, it is proven that Israel is committing crimes of genocide, war, aggression and crimes against humanity, crimes typified by the law, intentional and persecuted.by the International Criminal Court.Faced with this situation of the military assassinating the civilian population, the equidistance is obscene.The freezing of the Association Agreement with the State of Israel or any type of sanction against it is not requested, losing the opportunity to demand compliance with international law.I have therefore decided to vote against this resolution.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. - Conflict is our conflict. It skims our borders, as well as touching our consciences. The European Union is the only true political-institutional subject, endowed with the authority and credit necessary to act as a mediator to put an end to hostilities and to restore a serious dialogue aimed not only at lasting peace, but at resolving unresolved issues . We must provide political support and coverage to all interlocutors who agree to sit at a table and who reject violence as a means of conflict resolution on principle. It is said that Europe does not have its own foreign policy and perhaps it is true, however it is free from ideological preconceptions towards the contenders and this makes it the only credible interlocutor. The hope is that the new Commission will be able to really give an active role to the High Representative, becoming the protagonist of a new season in foreign policy, starting right from the battered lands on our borders.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing.- Faced with the resurgence of violence between Israel and Palestine, the European Parliament calls on the authorities responsible for an immediate ceasefire agreement between the two parties.This resolution rightly underlines the need for a de-escalation of violence in order to ensure the safety of civilians.Too many are those who have already died since the resumption of violence.We therefore call for international humanitarian law to be respected in this conflict.That is why I wanted to vote in favor of this resolution.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - It is said that watching a crime and doing nothing is to be an accomplice. But what could be called this position of the majority of the European Parliament, which, in view of Israel's racist and genocidal attitude, calls, in the first point of this resolution, to put an end to the rocket attacks against Israel from Gaza? What can be called laundering the aggression of one of the best-armed and best-trained armies in the world against defenseless Palestinians, murdering hundreds of people wherever they are, men, women and children - no one escapes - and destroying infrastructure, already on their own precarious as a result of the criminal Israeli occupation, including hospitals and water supplies? What can be called those who manipulate reality, once again transforming the aggressor into a victim, exonerating those who have kept hundreds of thousands of Palestinians in a system of isolation, siege and ghettoization, namely in Gaza, where the need for the most basic needs to human life increases every minute in the face of this brutal Israeli attack? What can be called the evident contempt for the human lives of the Palestinians that the majority of Parliament reveals with this false equidistance, with a neutrality that hides support and collusion with Israel?

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing.- It is not for nothing that it is said that the one who resolves the conflict in the Middle East deserves all the world's awards.The situation between Israel and Palestine is repeated periodically.If we want to be objective, we must recognize that Israel is the only real democracy in the region, surrounded by a country with a not very friendly policy towards the state of Israel.Nevertheless, Israel has long sought a non-conflicting and mutually acceptable solution, which, however, has not been accepted by Palestine.In any case, I condemn any violence perpetrated against the population on both sides and call on the representatives of the democratic state of Israel to try to make efforts to resolve the current conflict and maintain peace without military intervention.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing.- Civilian populations cannot be deliberately targeted by attacks.The Israeli and Palestinian populations have the right to live in peace and security.We must at all costs prevent an escalation of the conflict.For this to happen, the international community must engage promptly with key regional actors to ensure that a ceasefire occurs and peace talks resume.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I wished to be a co-signatory of the resolution on the ongoing conflict between Israel and Palestine, a conflict which is causing further tragic loss of life and unacceptable suffering to the civilian populations on both sides, in Gaza and in Israel.Through its mediating power, the European Union must convince the two parties to put an end to the escalation of violence, to restore the ceasefire of November 2012 and to resume direct negotiations as soon as possible with a view tofinally, to reach a lasting and comprehensive peace agreement based on the coexistence of two States.

name: Kaja Kallas (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I support the resolution and hope that an opportunity will be found to continue the peace talks.I am not in favor of unilateral action, and I continue to believe that lasting peace in the Middle East is possible through a two-state solution.At 2.05, the unity government of Fatah and Hamas was sworn in in Palestine, with which the EU and the US pledged to continue working together with a consistent commitment to a two-state solution and Israeli right to exist, non-violence and general respect for the Middle East Quartet.Due to the military operation in Gaza, day-to-day substantive cooperation is currently suspended.However, I hope that cooperation will continue.I call on the parties to the conflict to find peaceful solutions.The European Union must help the parties to the conflict to find solutions that will lead to lasting peace.

name: Γεώργιος Κατρούγκαλος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- I voted against the resolution because it misinterprets the causes that led to the recent crisis and underestimates the internationally recognized rights of the Palestinian people to their full democratic self-determination.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The joint resolution submitted to us focuses only on the tragic consequences of the bombings which it attributes to an escalation of tensions for which the Israelis and Palestinians are responsible. This approach seeking to put the two parties back to back legitimizes the incredible violence of Israel's response in the name of the right to defend itself and disregards its responsibility for this escalation. Namely: by the continuation of the occupation, that of colonization despite its illegality under international law, and that of the blockade of Gaza which imposes collective punishment on an entire people against all existing conventions . By making no mention of these serious facts, by calling for a lifting of the blockade of Gaza only as part of an unlikely general settlement of the conflict, this resolution gives credence to the lies distilled by the Israeli authorities and reinforces the feeling of impunity . This is why I voted against this text and supported that of my group of the European United Left / Nordic Green Left, much more critical of the policies carried out by Israel against the Palestinian people, while calling on Hamas to immediately cease firing.

name: Paloma López (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted against this resolution because I do not share the equidistance with which the parties are treated when Israel is massacring the civilian population.With more than 600 Palestinians killed in the Gaza Strip as a result of the Israeli attacks in its latest offensive, it is proven that Israel is committing crimes of genocide, war, aggression and crimes against humanity, crimes typified by the law, intentional and persecuted.by the International Criminal Court.Faced with this situation of the military killing the civilian population, equidistance is obscene.The freezing of the Association Agreement with the State of Israel or any type of sanction against it is not requested, losing the opportunity to demand compliance with international law.That is why I have decided to vote against this resolution.

name: Javier López Fernández (S&D)
text: written. - The situation in the Gaza Strip is intolerable. On the tenth day of attacks since the Israeli military operation "Defensive Pillar" began; 213 people have already died (212 Palestinians and 1 Israeli), of whom at least 39 were children. Yesterday, Israel killed 4 children playing soccer on the Gaza beach by firing projectiles directly at them. In addition, the Israeli army has announced that it wants 100,000 Gazans to leave their homes and, according to UNWRA, there are 22,000 displaced Palestinians living in UN shelters, as the borders are closed. Gaza is a huge prison with 1.8 million Palestinians bombed by Israel. This morning Israel and Hamas agreed to a ceasefire for only five hours to allow humanitarian aid to enter Gaza, but it is not enough. This situation is a real human drama and we must make every effort to stop it. That is why I am voting in favor of this resolution, because any gesture and action is necessary to ask the parties to stop the violence and to return to negotiations to try to end a conflict that lasts forever.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution on the current escalation of violence between Israel and Palestine. That so many young people on both sides have been involved in this latest crisis, both at the start of the crisis and in the ongoing exchange, is tragic. The core roots of this crisis will not be solved easily, but I welcomed today’s five-hour agreed break from fire and that a tentative ceasefire has been agreed.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- As barbaric violence against Palestinians is unleashed by an Israeli government dominated by the far-right, this resolution aims to put both sides on the same level.While it calls for an end to Israeli military action against Gaza as well as an end to rocket fire at Israel from the Gaza Strip, at no time is the policy of collective sanctions pursued by Israel against the Palestinian people condemned.Finally, the issue of Israeli settlements in Palestinian territory is completely avoided.I vote against this unbalanced, hypocritical and unfair resolution.Especially since none of the very important means of pressure available to the EU vis-à-vis Israel is used to force its government to stop the massacre.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament's resolution on the escalation of violence between Israel and Palestine.Parliament calls on the international community to make serious efforts to relaunch peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians.In this regard, I argue that the European Union should play a more active role in efforts to achieve lasting peace in a conflict that is causing the loss of life and the suffering of the civilian population on both sides.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. - This resolution urges the International Community to increase their efforts in finding a workable and immediate solution to the current conflict and stresses the need for a rapid de-escalation of the violence against innocent civilians. Furthermore, it stresses the belief that both Israeli and Palestinian citizens have the right to live in peace and security and that both sides need to ensure that international law is followed and respected. This is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. - I am in favour of this resolution, which calls for serious and credible efforts by both sides and the international community to resume direct peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians, and to achieve concrete results in these talks. It urges the EU and its Member States to play a more active political role in this regard, including through a European peace initiative and plan. Last but not least the resolution stresses that both Israeli citizens and Palestinian citizens have the right to live in peace and security; and stresses the need for all sides to respect international humanitarian law. That is why I voted in favour

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution which calls for a rapid solution to the conflict between Israel and Palestine.International mediation must be put in place to allow Israeli and Palestinian citizens to live in peace.I stress that the European Union is the main contributor of humanitarian aid in the region and that as such, the Union must play a much more proactive role in the search for a solution.

name: Massimo Paolucci (S&D)
text: in writing.- (IT) Mr President, unfortunately I was unable to take part in the vote on the resolution presented on the dramatic events that are involving the Gaza Strip.But, given the importance of the arguments, I would like to leave a written declaration of mine and the expression of my support for the adopted text on record.There is no more time.The escalation of violence in the Gaza Strip must be stopped.We must insist with determination to obtain an immediate ceasefire, as proposed by Egypt.Innocent deaths, lack of water, food and medicine multiply the tensions.Anger and despair generate hatred and strengthen extremists.It is a wrong choice, a dramatic illusion to think that, in this way, Israel can guarantee its people a more secure future.Europe cannot waver, its southern borders have become a powder keg.Effective and immediate diplomatic action is needed.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: in writing. - The European Parliamentary Group of the KKE denounces the unacceptable joint resolution of the political coalition of capital in the European Parliament (People's Party, Social Democrats, Liberals, Conservatives-Reformists), which puts in the place of the accused the Palestinian struggle Under the pretext of the security of the state of Israel, it justifies the barbaric murderous attacks of the Israeli occupation forces, acquits the state of Israel for the brutal war crimes against Palestinian civilians, children, women and the elderly. There is not a single word in the joint resolution condemning the Israeli attack, the killing of hundreds of Palestinians, and even the babies of children, while calling the massacre of civilians by Israel's war machine in Gaza a "critical situation." By keeping equal distances and equating criminals with their victims, it effectively supports murderous Israeli attacks, intimidates and encourages Israeli aggression. For the umpteenth time, the European Parliament is at the forefront of EU-US-NATO imperialist plans. , to safeguard the interests of the monopoly companies they represent, to ensure the plunder of the rich sources of wealth and the exploitation of the peoples of the region. The demand of the KKE, the working people's movement in Greece, is to stop now the bombing and the land massacre of the Palestinian people by Israel.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution to call for an immediate ceasefire on violence between Israelis and Palestinians.I also supported a stronger involvement of the EU in the resolution of this conflict but opposition from right-wing parties did not allow this point to be adopted.As Israel's first trading partner, Europe must push for a serious resumption of the peace process between the two parties and for the two-state solution to emerge.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. - I voted for the resolution on the escalation of violence between Israel and Palestine calling for a ceasefire. The situation is getting worse every day. Rocket fire follows bombardment and vice versa. De-escalation and an immediate cessation of violence are necessary to reach a peace solution because the images of the victims and the destruction are unbearable.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution which calls for the immediate de-escalation of the conflict in the Middle East by a ceasefire agreement between the two sides and an immediate end to all acts of violence that threaten the lives of the civilian population. In this resolution, Parliament called for an immediate end to rocket attacks on Israel from Gaza and an end to all Israeli military action against Gaza. Extremely concerned about the critical situation in the Gaza Strip and southern Israel, Parliament also called on the EU High Representative to step up diplomatic pressure to support efforts to negotiate a permanent truce, and called on the international community to immediately find an appropriate response and solution to the current crisis. For there is no justification for attacks deliberately targeting innocent civilians. I also voted for an amendment (finally not included in the text) which called on the EU to assume its responsibilities and launch a clear and comprehensive peace initiative for the region and to use all means at its disposal to ensure effective respect for international humanitarian law and human rights.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. – The struggle of every people against the conqueror for his freedom and independence is the most sacred and non-negotiable. The obligation and duty of all free people, and to the fullest extent of what we owe our freedom and independence today to the struggles and sacrifices of our ancestors, is to support in every way and by all means the struggle for freedom and independence of the peoples. I refuse to give the slightest attenuation to any conqueror. I refuse to give even a minimum of my full support to those who are fighting for the freedom of their country. I refuse to co-sign a resolution characterising every Palestinian who fights for his freedom as a terrorist and baptizes the Israeli occupier as a defender, by apologizing to him for all his heinous crimes.

name: Jordi Sebastià (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - I voted against this resolution because when in a conflict between two one of its members has much more military strength and power than the other, as is the case of Israel over Hamas, equidistance is an injustice. Because I do not want to be ashamed to be responsible for such a lukewarm statement against the massacres of Palestinian civilians that Israel is perpetrating and for which this un blunt resolve makes us complicit.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this resolution because I do not share the equidistance with which the parties are treated when Israel is massacring civilians. With more than 600 Palestinians killed in the Gaza Strip as a result of Israeli attacks in its latest offensive, Israel is proven to be committing crimes of genocide, war, aggression and humanity, crimes criminalized by intentional law and pursued by the International Criminal Court. In the face of this situation of military killing civilians, equidistance is obscene. No freezing of the Association Agreement with the State of Israel or any sanction against it is requested, losing the opportunity to claim compliance with international law. That is why I have decided to vote against this resolution.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. As an MEP who is very committed to human rights and respect for our values here, I am very concerned about the current situation. The Israeli government is under pressure from its extremist fringe to reject any concessions. They dream of ending Hamas, a highly unlikely goal. These ministers are preaching in favour of a ground military intervention designed to disarm Hamas. Such an offensive would cause dozens of Israeli casualties, which could quickly cause it to lose the support of Israeli public opinion. Yet there is no military solution in Gaza: an Israeli "victory" against Hamas would make the bed of jihadist groups ambushed on the other side of the Egyptian border, and exalted by the advent of their "caliph" in Iraq. Israel would repeat with even more dramatic consequences the mistake made ten years earlier, when it weakened the Palestinian Authority in favour of Hamas. A recapture of Gaza, as demanded by the hard right, is not an option. It's pure demagoguery. Sooner or later, a new ceasefire will be reached. But this is not an end in itself, if it is only a matter of waiting for the next confrontation.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I did not add my name and co-sign the ALDE resolution text regarding the escalation of the situation between Israel and Palestine because I did not find it balanced enough. I think that Europe should not forget that, according to the Israeli Government at the moment I write, 300 rockets were fired from the Gaza Strip into Israel from mid-June until 7 July whereas, according to the Israel defence forces, more than 1000 rockets have been launched from the Gaza Strip to Israel since 7 July 2014, aimed at targets as far as Jerusalem, Tel Aviv and the north of the country. Moreover, in my view, the EU should call on Hamas and Palestinian organisations to cease using civilian populations as human shields in the hostilities. This is really a crime against humanity. Both parties should refrain from excessive violence and respect the ceasefire. I repeat both parties in this conflict.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - The text of the finally agreed resolution is equidistant and does not contain a strong condemnation of the actions of the State of Israel, the systematic violation of international law and the heinous crimes committed these days in Gaza. That is why I have decided to vote against the Resolution.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this resolution because I do not share the equidistance with which the parties are treated when Israel is massacring civilians. With more than 600 Palestinians killed in the Gaza Strip as a result of Israeli attacks in its latest offensive, Israel is proven to be committing crimes of genocide, war, aggression and humanity, crimes criminalized by intentional law and pursued by the International Criminal Court. In the face of this situation of military killing civilians, equidistance is obscene. No freezing of the Association Agreement with the State of Israel or any sanction against it is requested, losing the opportunity to claim compliance with international law. That is why I have decided to vote against this resolution.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - It's said that watching a crime and doing nothing is being an accomplice. But what can be called this attitude of the majority of the EP which, in the face of Israel's racist and genocidal attitude, asks, in the first point of this resolution, to put an end to rocket attacks against Israel from Gaza? What can be called by the whitening of the attack of the world's fourth best-trained and trained army against the defenseless Palestinians, murdering hundreds of people wherever they are, men, women and children - no one escapes - and destroying their infrastructure, including hospitals, water supply plants? What can be called those who manipulate reality, once again turning the aggressor beast into the purest victim, exonerating those who have kept hundreds of thousands of Palestinians in a system of isolation, siege and ghettoization, particularly in Gaza, where the lack of the most basic needs for human life increases every minute in the face of this brutal Israeli attack?  What can be called the obvious contempt for the human lives of palestinians that the majority of the EP reveals with this false equidistance, with a neutrality that hides support and collusion with Israel?

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because of our strong commitment to the development, defence and enforcement of international law. This resolution shows support for the work of the International Criminal Court in the revision of the Rome Statute with Kampala's amendments typifying the Crime of Aggression. This new typification is an important development that can serve to end the impunity of many States. Only thirty States have so far ratified this amendment to the Treaty of Rome, so this resolution supporting it is an important draw of attention to the Member States for ratification. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Andrus Ansip (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported the resolution on the crime of aggression. Today we endorsed the resolution about the situation in Ukraine. Crime of aggression is not a theoretical matter. It is something we have to face in Europe today. Thus, I would like to endorse all steps that strengthen the International Criminal Court and the advance of the global justice system. EU must continue to support the ICC both politically and diplomatically, as well as logistically and financially.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) After careful reflection and discussion in this House, I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the crime of aggression, having also firmly believed, as stated in the text of the resolution, that it is essential that all EU Member States commit themselves to combating genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes. I am also convinced that we need to support calls to include the fight against impunity for serious human rights violations among the priorities of the EU's external action, as well as those of its Member States. I am confident that, also through the action of the European Parliament, the impunity of the perpetrators of the most serious crimes will be brought to an end, which is a cause for alarm for the international community.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. - The inclusion of the crime of aggression in the ius cogens is a step towards the definitive condemnation of the war as an instrument for resolving disputes between sovereign states. It is these inhuman and unworthy acts of civil society that have so strongly united the peoples of Europe since the Second World War. They are what has strongly led us to create bodies to prevent any entity, whether we want to call it a state or not, from still committing acts of this kind.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) The joint resolution, for which I voted, has struck a rather predictable balance with regard to the crime of aggression. This is an issue on which it is easy to agree, but which is not one of the priorities of any State and which therefore always remains open. It is no coincidence that many countries, including Italy, have not yet fulfilled their commitments in this field. The resolution that I helped to adopt is an important political declaration in favour of this principle, and I hope that the Member States themselves will be able to follow up quickly.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because of our strong commitment to the development, defence and enforcement of international law. This resolution shows support for the work of the International Criminal Court in the revision of the Rome Statute with Kampala's amendments typifying the Crime of Aggression. This new typification is an important development that can serve to end the impunity of many States. Only thirty States have so far ratified this amendment to the Treaty of Rome, so this resolution supporting it is an important draw of attention to the Member States for ratification. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. - I believe that the fight against genocide, crimes against humanity, war crimes must be a priority for the external actions of the European Union and the Member States, and I believe that it is important at Union level to adopt a common position on the crime of aggression.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This resolution reiterates support for the International Criminal Court which we do not share. First of all, it is an international judicial body to prosecute crimes against humanity, whose independence is not guaranteed due to its dependence on the UN Security Council, that is, its use as a political instrument by winners against losers, an instrument of the law of the strongest - remember the example of the ad hoc tribunal for the former Yugoslavia. And that statute remains the basis for the existence of this court. Secondly, as advocated in this resolution, the rapid harmonisation of the national laws of the Member States, in order to align them with the Kampala amendments as well as with other obligations under the Rome Statute, constitutes an unacceptable attempt to meddling in the internal law of the Member States, in particular in the Portuguese, in its legal tradition and in the principles on which it is founded. In particular, we refer to the consecration in the Rome Statute of the life sentence, a punishment which does not exist - and we argue that it does not exist - in the domestic law of countries such as Portugal.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. - Both the European Union and the Slovak Republic are staunch supporters and have long supported the existence of the International Criminal Court, as well as the universality of the Rome Statute. The addition and extension of the jurisdiction and scope of the jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court to the crime of aggression is an important legal step that will contribute to the functioning of the rule of law at international level and to international peace and security by discouraging the unlawful use of force and thereby contributing to ending impunity for the perpetrators of such crimes. I also support the resolution tabled because it is one of the mechanisms by which we can combat crimes against humanity, genocide, human rights violations and so on. It is precisely in these difficult times that it is important to actively contribute to peacekeeping and maintenance at all costs and at all times.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. - The Kampala compromise from the Rome Statute Review Conference of the International Criminal Court in June 2010 led to a common definition of the crime of aggression, which is a significant step forward. States have, in fact, agreed to define by a crime of aggression the planning, preparation, launch or execution by a person who is effectively able to control or direct the political or military action of a state, an act of aggression which, by its nature, gravity and magnitude, constitutes a clear violation of the Charter of the United Nations. Nevertheless, the conditions for exercising the Court's jurisdiction over the crime of aggression, in accordance with the prerogatives of the Security Council, are not met. Paragraph 8 of Article 15bis of the Kampala Compromise is not unanimous in that it amounts to limiting the role of the Security Council, when it alone has the power to find a crime of aggression under the United Nations Charter. Consistency and complementarity between the International Criminal Court and the Security Council must therefore be sought. That is why I abstained at the time of the final vote.

name: Paloma López (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because of our strong commitment to the development, defence and enforcement of international law. This resolution shows support for the work of the International Criminal Court in the revision of the Rome Statute with Kampala's amendments typifying the Crime of Aggression. This new typification is an important development that can serve to end the impunity of many States. Only thirty States have so far ratified this amendment to the Treaty of Rome, so this resolution supporting it is an important draw of attention to the Member States for ratification. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Monica Luisa Macovei (PPE)
text: in writing. - I join my colleagues in expressing our full support to the work of the International Criminal Court and to the promotion of peace through criminal justice. The definition of the crime of aggression as stated during the Kampala Conference in 2010 reflects a compromise made by many States with the aim to ensure a high efficiency of the ICC in cases when armed force is used by one State against another State, without the justification of self-defence or without authorization by the Security Council. These cases are the current reality if we look at the horrific violence in Ukraine or Moldova. I encourage all the Member States to align their national criminal legislation with the Kampala Amendments' definitions in order to achieve the goal of having the dispositions on the crime of aggression entered into force and in order to have the possibility to hold account the responsible persons. I further urge all nations to put aside political or commercial interests and ratify and implement the amendments. It is thus critical to make every effort possible to ensure that we have the legal framework to condemn such deplorable cases.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because it is important that, if possible, the EU comes to a common agreement on these Kampala amendments to the Rome Agreement. If ratified these amendments will be an important development in international law and will allow yet another legal deterrent to states to commit human rights abuses.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The concept of the crime of aggression defines crimes committed by persons or states that have prepared, carried out or promoted an armed conflict aimed at destabilizing one or more sovereign states. The definition of the crime of aggression has been set in the Rome Statute since 2010. In order for the International Criminal Court to have jurisdiction over this crime, at least 30 states must ratify the Kampala amendments. This resolution calls on Member States to ratify them and incorporate these provisions into their national legislation. I'm voting for.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution calling on the European Union to upforce the Kampala amendment on the crime of aggression and to support efforts to implement it.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. - This resolution highlights the EU’s commitment in combatting acts of genocide, crime against humanity, war crimes and the crime of aggression and urges the establishment of permanent system of international criminal accountability for those committing such a crime. It is for this reason why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. It is essential to make the protection of human life a top priority. In Kampala, ICC states parties reached a compromise on the crime of aggression. However, we can only regret the difficulties associated with its implementation. Thus, it would be necessary to wait until 2 January 2017 for the ICC to exercise its jurisdiction over the crime of aggression, provided that thirty States have ratified the amendments relating to the crime of aggression before 1 January 2016 and that a decision of the Assembly of States Parties authorising the Court to exercise this jurisdiction will take place as early as 2 January 2017. Currently only twelve States Parties, including Belgium, have ratified the amendments relating to the crime of aggression; which makes me say that the Kampala statement is a reflection of the challenges that the ICC faces: its impact on victims of crimes, the necessary cooperation of States in the investigation and arrest of the accused, and complementarity by intervening only as a last resort. Therefore, there is an urgent need for the EU to take the lead in the entry into force of the Kampala amendments on the crime of aggression.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text for reasons of effectiveness of international policy. Today, only the UN Security Council, of which France is one of the five permanent members, has the power to acknowledge the existence of an act of aggression. It is clear that justice is complementary to peace and that I fully support the actions of the International Criminal Court. However, in the name of the stability of international institutions and the effectiveness of their actions, the unique jurisdiction to characterize the crime of aggression must remain in the hands of the UN Security Council.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. - I support this resolution, which calls on the EU to commit to the fight against genocide, crimes against humanity, war crimes and the crime of aggression, as well as calling for combating impunity for grave human rights violations to be made a priority for the EU and for the Member States in their external actions. I have voted in favour.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. - I voted on the motion for a resolution on crimes of aggression. These crimes are included in the list of crimes under the jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court. But despite the lengthy process of negotiating the Statute of the Court adopted in Rome in 1998, states have failed to agree on its definition. Above all, the modalities for exercising the jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court in the implementation of prosecutions are not defined. I rejected the inclusion in this resolution of a reference to the Kampala amendments which could lead to having to choose between respect for the Charter of the United Nations and compliance with the Rome Statute. However, France, a member of the Security Council, cannot accept a new competing body of the Security Council, before which the States would come to bring their political-military differences. Such a situation would undermine the effectiveness and credibility of the Court itself.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because of our strong commitment to the development, defence and enforcement of international law. This resolution shows support for the work of the International Criminal Court in the revision of the Rome Statute with Kampala's amendments typifying the Crime of Aggression. This new typification is an important development that can serve to end the impunity of many States. Only thirty States have so far ratified this amendment to the Treaty of Rome, so this resolution supporting it is an important draw of attention to the Member States for ratification. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. As defined by the Assembly of States Parties in Kampala, the crime of aggression refers to the planning, preparation, initiation or commission of an act of one state using armed force against the sovereignty, territorial integrity or political independence of another state. Acts of aggression include invasion, military occupation or annexation by use of force and blockade of ports or coasts, if by their character, severity and scale, these acts are considered manifest violations of the Charter of the United Nations. I fully support this resolution, which aims to remind us that crimes of aggression are still commonplace around the world and to criticise the impunity enjoyed by too many criminals who commit these crimes. The entry into office of the International Criminal Court (ICC) in 2002 ushered in a new era of global responsibility and ushered in an end to impunity. I also believe that the Kampala Conference, like this resolution, is an opportunity to underline our collective determination to ensure that crimes against humanity do not go unpunished.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because of our strong commitment to the development, defence and enforcement of international law. This resolution shows support for the work of the International Criminal Court in the revision of the Rome Statute with Kampala's amendments typifying the Crime of Aggression. This new typification is an important development that can serve to end the impunity of many States. Only thirty States have so far ratified this amendment to the Treaty of Rome, so this resolution supporting it is an important draw of attention to the Member States for ratification. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Jarosław Leszek Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Resolution on the crime of aggression (2014/2724(RSP)), the reason being that I fully support the Rome Statute and the ʽKampala Amendmentsʼ. It is vital that the European Union cooperates with, and continues to support the International Criminal Court (ICC) and plays a role in the establishment of the Courtʼs jurisdiction. Thus, we as Member States must all agree that the crime of aggression defined in the Statute as ʽthe planning, preparation, initiation or execution by a personʼ in a leadership position is ʽan act of aggressionʼ. Importantly, it contains the threshold requirement that the act of aggression must constitute ʽa manifest violation of the Charter of the United Nationsʼ. Therefore, it is clear that the EU would not, and cannot, accept such acts based on the above definition and must stand united in implementing the amendments as to lend to the continued aforementioned support of the ICC as well as the United Nations Charter on Human Rights.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This resolution reiterates support for the International Criminal Court which we do not share. First of all, it is an international judicial body to prosecute crimes against humanity, whose independence is not guaranteed due to its dependence on the UN Security Council, that is, its use as a political instrument by winners against losers, an instrument of the law of the strongest - remember the example of the ad hoc tribunal for the former Yugoslavia. And that statute remains the basis for the existence of this court. Secondly, as advocated in this resolution, the rapid harmonisation of the national laws of the Member States, in order to align them with the Kampala amendments as well as with other obligations under the Rome Statute, constitutes an unacceptable attempt to meddling in the internal law of the Member States, in particular in the Portuguese, in its legal tradition and in the principles on which it is founded. In particular, we refer to the consecration in the Rome Statute of the life sentence, a punishment which does not exist - and we argue that it does not exist - in the domestic law of countries such as Portugal.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: That concludes the explanations of vote. I wish all my colleagues who are still there a good way home and a relaxing summer break. I would particularly like to thank the services here on the left, on the right and behind me, especially the interpreters in the cabins. You have now earned a summer break. Also a good way home! Mr Valli has also raised a point of order.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, you were very kind to give me the floor. I am saddened to speak to such an empty Chamber, as my colleague has just described it. I wanted to remind you that we are here paid handsomely by taxpayers to do a job and if we are paid to do this we should do it with the utmost consistency and competence. It seems to me, however, that there is no respect for this work on the part of my colleagues, because I have seen statements made in total chaos. You said these people had to go get an airplane. We are not paid to take airplanes, we are paid to stay here and work and work with the utmost seriousness.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: Mr Valli, I would like to thank Mr Valli for his They are new, so I have not withdrawn the floor from you. You have not raised a point of order. That was a general political statement. You are also paid to follow the rules.

I think the last speaker was somewhat unfair to Members who may not have any alternative to getting a plane at this particular time.
